**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section may have limited or indirect relevance to personal tax filing depending on the individual's specific tax situation.

### §1397B. Nonrecognition of gain on rollover of empowerment zone investments

This section allowed taxpayers who sold qualified empowerment zone assets held for more than one year to defer recognition of gain by reinvesting the proceeds in another qualified empowerment zone asset within 60 days. The gain was recognized only to the extent the amount realized exceeded the cost of the replacement asset. The section terminated for sales in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2020.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is no longer relevant for current personal tax filing because it terminated after the 2020 tax year. Historically, it could have applied to individual taxpayers who held and sold empowerment zone investments.

### §1397C. Enterprise zone business defined

This section defines the term "enterprise zone business" for purposes of the empowerment zone tax incentives. A qualifying entity must conduct active business within an empowerment zone, derive at least 50 percent of its gross income from such business, use a substantial portion of its tangible and intangible property within the zone, and employ at least 35 percent of its workforce from zone residents.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It provides a definitional framework used by other empowerment zone provisions. A sole proprietor operating within an empowerment zone would have used this definition to determine eligibility for empowerment zone tax incentives, but those incentives have largely expired.

### §1397D. Qualified zone property defined

This section defines "qualified zone property" as depreciable tangible property acquired by purchase after the empowerment zone designation took effect, with original use commencing with the taxpayer in the zone, and substantially all use occurring in the active conduct of a qualified business within the zone. It also includes substantially renovated property meeting certain cost thresholds.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It supports definitions for empowerment zone incentives that primarily applied to businesses, and the empowerment zone designations have largely expired.

### §1397E. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section, which provided a credit to holders of qualified zone academy bonds, was repealed in 2017.

### §1397F. Regulations

This section authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to prescribe regulations necessary to carry out the purposes of the empowerment zone tax incentive provisions, including rules to prevent abuse, limit over-subsidization by the federal government, and deal with inadvertent failures of entities to qualify as enterprise zone businesses.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It is an administrative provision authorizing regulatory guidance for empowerment zone tax incentives.

### §1398. Rules relating to individuals' title 11 cases

This section establishes the tax treatment of bankruptcy estates for individual debtors under Chapter 7 or Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. It creates the bankruptcy estate as a separate taxable entity, provides for the computation of its tax using married-filing-separately rates, and governs the transfer of tax attributes (such as NOL carryovers, capital loss carryovers, and credits) between the debtor and the estate. It also allows the debtor to elect to split the taxable year into two short years at the commencement of the bankruptcy case.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is highly relevant to individuals who file for personal bankruptcy. It governs how income, deductions, and credits are allocated between the individual debtor and the bankruptcy estate, and affects what must be reported on the individual's personal tax return during and after bankruptcy.

### §1399. No separate taxable entities for partnerships, corporations, etc.

This section provides that, except for individual bankruptcy cases covered by section 1398, no separate taxable entity is created when a partnership, corporation, or other entity commences a case under Title 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It clarifies that bankruptcy of a business entity does not create a separate tax entity, which is a matter for business entity taxation.

### §§1400 to 1400C. Repealed

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections, which related to the DC Zone tax incentives including zero percent capital gains rates and a first-time homebuyer credit for the District of Columbia, were repealed in 2018.

### §§1400E to 1400J. Repealed

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections, which related to renewal community tax incentives, were repealed in 2018.

### §§1400L to 1400U-3. Repealed

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections, which related to tax benefits for the New York Liberty Zone, Gulf Opportunity Zone, and recovery zone bonds, were repealed in 2018.

### §1400Z-1. Designation

This section establishes the framework for designating qualified opportunity zones. It defines a qualified opportunity zone as a low-income community population census tract nominated by the chief executive of a state and certified by the Secretary of the Treasury. The section specifies criteria for low-income communities based on median family income and poverty rates, limits the number of designations per state, and provides that each designation lasts for 10 years. As amended in 2025, the section provides for new decennial determination periods beginning July 1, 2026.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to personal tax filing because it establishes the geographic framework for the Opportunity Zone program. Individual taxpayers who invest capital gains in qualified opportunity funds (under section 1400Z-2) must know whether the fund invests in designated qualified opportunity zones.

### §1400Z-2. Special rules for capital gains invested in opportunity zones

This section provides the tax incentive rules for capital gains invested in qualified opportunity funds. A taxpayer may elect to defer gain from the sale of property by investing the gain in a qualified opportunity fund within 180 days. The deferred gain is included in income upon the earlier of sale of the investment or a specified date (December 31, 2026 under current law, or 5 years after investment under the 2025 amendments for post-2026 investments). Investments held for at least 5 years receive a 10% basis step-up. Investments held for at least 10 years may elect to have their basis equal to fair market value, potentially eliminating tax on appreciation in the opportunity zone investment itself.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is highly relevant to personal tax filing for individuals who have capital gains and choose to invest them in qualified opportunity funds. It affects the timing and amount of capital gains recognition on the individual's return and can provide significant tax deferral and reduction benefits.

### §1401. Rate of tax

This section imposes the self-employment tax on the self-employment income of every individual. It consists of two components: a 12.4% tax for old-age, survivors, and disability insurance (OASDI), and a 2.9% tax for hospital insurance (Medicare). An additional 0.9% Medicare tax applies to self-employment income exceeding $250,000 for joint filers, $125,000 for married filing separately, or $200,000 for other filers, for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The section also provides relief from these taxes where covered by international social security agreements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing for anyone with self-employment income. Self-employed individuals must calculate and pay self-employment tax using Schedule SE, and the rates specified in this section determine the amount of that tax.

### §1402. Definitions

This section provides comprehensive definitions for Chapter 2 (Self-Employment Contributions Act), most importantly defining "net earnings from self-employment" and "self-employment income." Net earnings from self-employment is gross income from a trade or business less allowable deductions, plus the individual's distributive share of partnership income, with numerous exclusions for rentals, dividends, interest, capital gains, and certain other items. Self-employment income is net earnings above $400, capped at the Social Security contribution and benefit base for the OASDI portion.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing for any individual with income from self-employment or partnership interests. It determines which types of income are subject to self-employment tax and which are excluded, directly affecting the computation on Schedule SE.

### §1403. Miscellaneous provisions

This section provides that Chapter 2 may be cited as the "Self-Employment Contributions Act of 1954" and contains cross references to provisions on returns (section 6017) and collection of taxes in the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Puerto Rico (section 7651).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It is a housekeeping provision with cross-references.

### §1411. Imposition of tax

This section imposes the Net Investment Income Tax (NIIT), a 3.8% tax on the lesser of an individual's net investment income or the excess of modified adjusted gross income over threshold amounts ($250,000 for joint filers, $125,000 for married filing separately, $200,000 for others). Net investment income includes interest, dividends, annuities, royalties, rents, passive activity income, and net gain from disposition of non-business property, reduced by allocable deductions. The tax also applies to estates and trusts. It does not apply to nonresident aliens or distributions from qualified retirement plans.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is highly relevant to personal tax filing for individuals with investment income whose modified adjusted gross income exceeds the threshold amounts. The NIIT is calculated on Form 8960 and added to the individual's tax liability on Form 1040.

### §1441. Withholding of tax on nonresident aliens

This section requires any person having control, receipt, custody, or payment of income from U.S. sources to a nonresident alien individual or foreign partnership to deduct and withhold tax at a rate of 30% (or 14% for certain scholarship/fellowship income). The income items subject to withholding include interest, dividends, rent, salaries, wages, and other fixed or determinable income. Numerous exceptions apply, including for income effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business, portfolio interest, certain annuities under qualified plans, and gambling winnings.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to personal tax filing primarily for nonresident aliens who receive U.S.-source income. U.S. persons making payments to nonresident aliens need to comply with these withholding requirements, but the section does not typically affect a U.S. citizen's or resident's own personal return.

### §1442. Withholding of tax on foreign corporations

This section extends the withholding requirements of section 1441 to foreign corporations subject to U.S. taxation, requiring deduction and withholding at the source at a 30% rate on the same items of income applicable to nonresident aliens. It provides exemptions where the Secretary determines the administrative burden is undue, and special rules for possessions corporations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It governs withholding obligations on payments to foreign corporations, which is a matter for the payor (typically a business or financial institution) rather than an individual filer.

### §1443. Foreign tax-exempt organizations

This section applies withholding requirements to income of foreign organizations that are subject to the tax on unrelated business taxable income under section 511, and to income of foreign organizations subject to the excise tax under section 4948(a), with withholding at a 4% rate for the latter.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It governs withholding on income of foreign tax-exempt organizations.

### §1444. Withholding on Virgin Islands source income

This section limits the withholding tax on income received from sources within the Virgin Islands by U.S. citizens, resident aliens, and U.S. corporations to the rate of tax actually imposed on such income under section 871(a)(1) or 881.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section has limited relevance to personal tax filing. It may be relevant only to individuals receiving income from Virgin Islands sources who are subject to withholding under the territorial tax system.

### §1445. Withholding of tax on dispositions of United States real property interests

This section requires the transferee in a disposition of a U.S. real property interest by a foreign person to withhold 15% of the amount realized. Several exemptions exist, including when the transferor provides a nonforeign affidavit, when the property is acquired as a residence for $300,000 or less, or when the stock is regularly traded. A reduced 10% withholding rate applies for residences where the amount realized does not exceed $1,000,000. The section also covers withholding on partnership and trust distributions of U.S. real property interests and on distributions by REITs and regulated investment companies.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to personal tax filing for U.S. individuals who purchase real property from foreign persons, as they have withholding obligations. It is also relevant to nonresident aliens selling U.S. real property interests, as the withheld amount can be credited against their U.S. tax liability.

### §1446. Withholding of tax on foreign partners' share of effectively connected income

This section requires partnerships with effectively connected taxable income allocable to foreign partners to withhold tax at the highest individual rate for non-corporate foreign partners and the highest corporate rate for corporate foreign partners. It also provides rules for withholding on dispositions of partnership interests where gain would be treated as effectively connected income, requiring a 10% withholding by the transferee. Foreign partners receive a credit for their share of withheld tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to most personal tax filers. It may be relevant to foreign individuals who are partners in U.S. partnerships, as it determines the withholding applied to their share of effectively connected income, which is then credited on their U.S. tax return.

### §1451. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section related to tax-free covenant bonds and was repealed in 1984.

### §1461. Liability for withheld tax

This section makes every person required to deduct and withhold tax under Chapter 3 (withholding on nonresident aliens and foreign corporations) liable for such tax and indemnifies them against claims from payees for amounts withheld in accordance with the chapter's provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It establishes liability rules for withholding agents, not for individual filers.

### §1462. Withheld tax as credit to recipient of income

This section provides that income subject to withholding at the source under Chapter 3 must be included in the recipient's return, and the amount withheld is credited against the recipient's income tax liability.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to nonresident aliens filing U.S. tax returns who can claim a credit for amounts withheld from their U.S.-source income.

### §1463. Tax paid by recipient of income

This section provides that if a withholding agent fails to deduct and withhold tax but the recipient subsequently pays the underlying tax, the withholding agent is relieved of liability for the withheld amount but not from liability for interest or penalties arising from the failure to withhold.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It governs the relationship between withholding agents and the IRS.

### §1464. Refunds and credits with respect to withheld tax

This section provides that where there has been an overpayment of tax under Chapter 3, refunds or credits are made to the withholding agent unless the tax was actually withheld from the payee.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It governs refund procedures for withholding agents.

### §1465. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section defined "withholding agent" and was repealed in 1976.

### §1471. Withholdable payments to foreign financial institutions

This section, part of FATCA (Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act), requires withholding agents to deduct and withhold 30% from withholdable payments made to foreign financial institutions (FFIs) that do not enter into an agreement with the Secretary to report information about U.S. accounts. Compliant FFIs must obtain account holder information, report on U.S. accounts annually, withhold from payments to recalcitrant account holders, and comply with Secretary requests for information. Exceptions exist for payments to foreign governments, international organizations, and foreign central banks.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing for most individuals. However, U.S. persons with accounts at foreign financial institutions may be indirectly affected, as their FFIs must report their account information to the IRS under these rules.

### §1472. Withholdable payments to other foreign entities

This section requires 30% withholding on withholdable payments to non-financial foreign entities unless the entity certifies it has no substantial U.S. owners or provides the names, addresses, and TINs of its substantial U.S. owners. Exceptions apply for publicly traded corporations, their affiliates, entities organized in U.S. possessions, foreign governments, and international organizations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It primarily affects withholding agents and foreign entities receiving U.S.-source payments.

### §1473. Definitions

This section provides key definitions for Chapter 4 (FATCA), including "withholdable payment" (U.S.-source interest, dividends, rents, salaries, and other FDAP income, plus gross proceeds from dispositions of property that can produce such income), "substantial United States owner" (generally persons owning more than 10% of a foreign entity), "specified United States person" (with exclusions for publicly traded corporations, tax-exempt organizations, banks, REITs, and others), "withholding agent," and "foreign entity."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing, but it defines the terms that determine when U.S. persons are reported on by foreign financial institutions under FATCA, which may trigger reporting obligations or correspondence from the IRS.

### §1474. Special rules

This section establishes liability, credit, and refund rules for Chapter 4 (FATCA) withholding. It makes withholding agents liable for withheld tax, provides rules for credits and refunds (with limitations for foreign financial institutions), requires beneficial owners seeking refunds to provide information about substantial U.S. owners, protects confidentiality of information, and coordinates FATCA withholding with other withholding provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. It provides administrative rules for FATCA withholding agents.

### §§1491, 1492. Repealed

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These former sections imposed a tax on certain transfers to foreign entities to avoid income tax and were repealed in 1997.

### §1493. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section defined "foreign trust" and was repealed in 1966.

### §1494. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section related to payment and collection of the excise tax on transfers to foreign entities and was repealed in 1997.

### §1501. Privilege to file consolidated returns

This section grants affiliated groups of corporations the privilege of filing a consolidated income tax return in lieu of separate returns. All member corporations must consent to the consolidated return regulations, and the consolidated return includes each member's income for the portion of the year it belongs to the group.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It applies exclusively to affiliated groups of corporations.

### §1502. Regulations

This section authorizes the Secretary to prescribe regulations governing consolidated returns by affiliated groups of corporations, covering determination, computation, assessment, collection, and adjustment of tax liability. The Secretary may prescribe rules different from regular Chapter 1 provisions that would apply if corporations filed separately.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It is a regulatory authority provision for corporate consolidated returns.

### §1503. Computation and payment of tax

This section governs the computation and payment of tax for affiliated groups filing consolidated returns. It includes special rules for applying net operating losses of non-insurance members against the income of insurance company members (limited to 35%), rules for dual consolidated losses (which cannot reduce income of other group members), and rules for determining basis adjustments to intragroup stock.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It applies exclusively to consolidated corporate tax returns.

### §1504. Definitions

This section defines "affiliated group" for consolidated return purposes as one or more chains of includible corporations connected through 80% stock ownership (by vote and value) with a common parent. It specifies which corporations are excluded from the definition of "includible corporation," such as tax-exempt organizations, insurance companies taxed under section 801, foreign corporations, regulated investment companies, DISCs, and S corporations. Special rules allow insurance companies to be included under certain elections.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It provides definitions used exclusively for corporate consolidated returns.

### §1505. Cross references

This section provides cross references to the statute of limitations provision (section 6503(a)(1)) and the allocation of income and deductions among related businesses (section 482).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It provides cross references for consolidated corporate return provisions.

### §1551. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section related to disallowance of graduated corporate rates and accumulated earnings credit benefits and was repealed in 2017.

### §1552. Earnings and profits

This section provides methods for allocating the tax liability of an affiliated group filing a consolidated return among the group members for purposes of determining each member's earnings and profits. Four methods are available, including allocation based on each member's share of consolidated taxable income, separate return tax liability, contribution to consolidated income, or any other Secretary-approved method. The default method applies the ratio of each member's taxable income to consolidated taxable income.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It applies exclusively to the determination of earnings and profits of corporate group members in consolidated returns.

### §1561. Limitation on accumulated earnings credit in the case of certain controlled corporations

This section limits component members of a controlled group of corporations to a single $250,000 ($150,000 for certain personal service corporations) accumulated earnings credit under section 535(c)(2) and (3) for their taxable years including the same December 31. The amount is divided equally among the component members unless regulations permit unequal allocation. Special rules apply for short taxable years.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It applies to controlled groups of corporations.

### §1562. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section related to elections for multiple surtax exemptions by controlled groups and was repealed in 1969.

### §1563. Definitions and special rules

This section defines "controlled group of corporations" for purposes of the controlled corporation provisions, encompassing parent-subsidiary groups (80% stock ownership chains), brother-sister groups (5 or fewer persons owning more than 50% of multiple corporations), combined groups, and certain insurance company groups. It provides detailed rules for determining component members, excluded members, stock exclusions, constructive ownership rules (including options, partnership/trust/corporate attribution, and family attribution), and operating rules.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing. However, its definitions of controlled groups are referenced by many other provisions throughout the Code that can affect individuals, such as rules for retirement plans and employment taxes.

### §1564. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section contained transitional rules for controlled corporations and was repealed in 1990.

### §2001. Imposition and rate of tax

This section imposes the federal estate tax on the transfer of the taxable estate of every decedent who is a citizen or resident of the United States. The tax is computed by applying the unified transfer tax rate schedule to cumulative lifetime and death-time transfers, then subtracting the gift taxes payable on lifetime transfers. The maximum rate is 40%. The computation also accounts for the unified credit (basic exclusion amount), adjusted taxable gifts, and state death tax credits.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not part of the individual income tax return (Form 1040) but is highly relevant to the personal finances of individuals whose estates may be subject to estate tax. Executors file Form 706 to report the estate tax. The basic exclusion amount affects estate planning decisions during life.

### §2002. Liability for payment

This section provides that the executor of the estate is liable for payment of the estate tax imposed by section 2001.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It establishes who is responsible for paying the estate tax.

### §2010. Unified credit against estate tax

This section provides a credit against the estate tax equal to the applicable credit amount, which is the tentative tax on the basic exclusion amount. The basic exclusion amount is $5,000,000 (adjusted for inflation; increased to $10,000,000 through 2025 by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, further increased to $15,000,000 through 2028 by subsequent legislation). The section also provides for portability of the deceased spousal unused exclusion amount (DSUE), allowing a surviving spouse to use their deceased spouse's unused exclusion.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not part of Form 1040, but it is extremely relevant to estate and financial planning for individuals. The portability provision requires filing an estate tax return even for non-taxable estates to elect DSUE transfer.

### §2012. Credit for gift tax

This section provides that the estate tax is credited by the amount of gift tax paid on property included in the decedent's gross estate. This prevents double taxation of the same transfer. The credit is limited to the smaller of the gift tax paid or the estate tax attributable to the inclusion of the gifted property.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It applies to estate tax computations on Form 706.

### §2013. Credit for tax on prior transfers

This section allows a credit against the estate tax for estate taxes paid on property transferred to the decedent from a prior transferor who died within 10 years before or 2 years after the decedent's death. The credit decreases by 20% for each two-year interval after the prior decedent's death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It applies to estate tax computations.

### §2014. Credit for foreign death taxes

This section allows a credit against the U.S. estate tax for estate, inheritance, or similar taxes paid to a foreign country on property situated in that country and included in the decedent's U.S. gross estate. The credit is limited to the lesser of the foreign tax attributable to the property or the proportion of the U.S. estate tax attributable to the foreign-situs property.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It applies to estate tax computations for decedents with foreign-situs property.

### §2015. Credit for death taxes on remainders

This section provides a special rule allowing the credit for state death taxes and foreign death taxes on reversionary or remainder interests to be taken at the time the interest comes into possession, if a timely election is made.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It applies to estate tax computations involving remainder interests.

### §2016. Recovery of taxes claimed as credit

This section requires that if any amount of state or foreign death taxes claimed as a credit against the federal estate tax is recovered by the estate, the executor must notify the Secretary and redetermine the estate tax. The additional tax must be paid.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It governs estate tax adjustments.

### §2031. Definition of gross estate

This section defines the gross estate for estate tax purposes as the value at the time of death of all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, wherever situated. It includes special rules for property transferred from insurance companies, unlisted stock and securities valuation, and the repeal of special estate tax valuation for real property in a farm or business. The section requires that the value of certain property be included regardless of whether the interest is considered a property right under state law.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It defines the gross estate for estate tax (Form 706) purposes.

### §2032. Alternate valuation

This section permits the executor to elect an alternate valuation date (generally 6 months after the decedent's death) for the gross estate, instead of the date-of-death valuation. This election can only be made if it decreases both the value of the gross estate and the estate tax liability. Property distributed, sold, or otherwise disposed of within the 6-month period is valued as of the date of disposition.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, but the election affects the basis of inherited property that passes to heirs, which in turn affects gain or loss calculations on the heirs' income tax returns.

### §2032A. Valuation of certain farm, etc., real property

This section allows the executor to elect to value certain qualified real property used in farming or a closely held business at its current-use value rather than its fair market value. The reduction from fair market value cannot exceed specified dollar limits (adjusted for inflation). The property must meet requirements for material participation and must pass to qualified heirs. A recapture tax applies if the property ceases to be used in the qualifying manner within 10 years of the decedent's death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, but the special use valuation affects the basis of inherited farm or business property, and the recapture tax may need to be reported if the property is later converted to a different use.

### §2033. Property in which the decedent had an interest

This section includes in the gross estate the value of all property to the extent of the interest therein of the decedent at the time of death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is a foundational estate tax provision.

### §2034. Dower or curtesy interests

This section provides that dower, curtesy, or statutory substitute interests are treated as transfers rather than interests held by the surviving spouse, and thus are included in the decedent's gross estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2035. Adjustments for certain gifts made within 3 years of decedent's death

This section includes in the decedent's gross estate the value of any gift tax paid by the decedent or the decedent's estate on gifts made within 3 years of death ("gross-up" rule). It also requires inclusion of the value of certain interests (life insurance, retained life estates, revocable transfers, and general powers of appointment) transferred within 3 years of death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing but is important for estate tax planning.

### §2036. Transfers with retained life estate

This section includes in the gross estate the value of property transferred during the decedent's life if the decedent retained the right to income, possession, or enjoyment of the property, or the right to designate who shall possess or enjoy the property, for the decedent's life or a period not ascertainable without reference to the decedent's death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is an estate tax provision affecting estate planning strategies involving retained interests.

### §2037. Transfers taking effect at death

This section includes in the gross estate the value of property transferred during the decedent's life if possession or enjoyment of the property can only be obtained by surviving the decedent, and the decedent retained a reversionary interest exceeding 5% of the value of the property immediately before death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is an estate tax inclusion provision.

### §2038. Revocable transfers

This section includes in the gross estate the value of property transferred during the decedent's life if, at the date of death, the enjoyment of the property was subject to change through the exercise of a power by the decedent to alter, amend, revoke, or terminate the transfer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is an estate tax provision governing revocable transfers, such as revocable trusts.

### §2039. Annuities

This section includes in the gross estate the value of annuities or other payments receivable by any beneficiary by reason of surviving the decedent, to the extent of the portion attributable to contributions made by the decedent. Exceptions exist for certain employer-provided annuities.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing, but it affects the estate tax treatment of survivor annuities, which may indirectly affect beneficiaries.

### §2040. Joint interests

This section provides rules for including jointly held property in the gross estate. Generally, for joint tenancies (other than between spouses), the full value is included except for the portion attributable to the survivor's consideration. For qualified joint interests between spouses, only 50% of the value is included in the estate of the first spouse to die.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing, but it affects the basis of jointly held property received by the survivor, which impacts future capital gains calculations.

### §2041. Powers of appointment

This section includes in the gross estate the value of property over which the decedent possessed a general power of appointment at death, or which the decedent exercised or released during life in a manner that would have triggered inclusion under sections 2035-2038. A general power of appointment is one exercisable in favor of the decedent, the decedent's estate, creditors, or creditors of the estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is an estate tax provision.

### §2042. Proceeds of life insurance

This section includes in the gross estate the proceeds of life insurance on the decedent's life receivable by the executor, and proceeds receivable by other beneficiaries if the decedent possessed any incidents of ownership in the policy at death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It determines when life insurance proceeds are included in the taxable estate.

### §2043. Transfers for insufficient consideration

This section provides that if a transfer subject to estate tax inclusion under sections 2035-2038 was made for consideration in money or money's worth, only the excess of the fair market value of the property at the time of death (or alternate valuation date) over the consideration received is included in the gross estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is an estate tax provision.

### §2044. Certain property for which marital deduction was previously allowed

This section includes in the gross estate the value of any property for which a marital deduction was previously allowed to the estate of the decedent's spouse under section 2056(b)(7) (qualified terminable interest property, or QTIP). This ensures that the property is eventually taxed in one estate or the other.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It is an estate tax provision related to QTIP trusts.

### §2045. Prior interests

This section provides that sections 2034 through 2042 apply to interests arising before the applicable dates of those sections, and that the provisions do not reduce the estate below what it would have been under prior law.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2046. Disclaimers

This section provides that for estate tax purposes, a qualified disclaimer under section 2518 is treated as if the disclaimed interest had never been transferred to the person making the disclaimer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing, but disclaimers can affect the distribution of assets and thus indirectly affect the income of beneficiaries.

### §2051. Definition of taxable estate

This section defines the taxable estate as the gross estate minus the deductions allowed by sections 2053 through 2058 (for expenses, losses, charitable transfers, marital deduction, and state death taxes).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It defines the taxable estate for Form 706 purposes.

### §2053. Expenses, indebtedness, and taxes

This section allows deductions from the gross estate for funeral expenses, administration expenses, claims against the estate (including debts of the decedent), and unpaid mortgages and indebtedness on property included in the gross estate. The amounts deductible are limited to those allowable under the laws of the jurisdiction governing the estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It provides deductions for estate tax purposes.

### §2054. Losses

This section allows a deduction from the gross estate for losses incurred during settlement of the estate arising from fires, storms, shipwrecks, or other casualties, or from theft, to the extent not compensated by insurance.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It provides a deduction for estate tax purposes.

### §2055. Transfers for public, charitable, and religious uses

This section allows a deduction from the gross estate for the value of property transferred to or for the use of the United States, any state, the District of Columbia, charitable organizations, religious organizations, fraternal organizations, and veterans' organizations. Special rules apply for split-interest trusts and the valuation of partial interests.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It provides the charitable deduction for estate tax purposes.

### §2056. Bequests, etc., to surviving spouse

This section provides an unlimited marital deduction from the gross estate for the value of property passing from the decedent to the surviving spouse. Special rules address terminable interests (which generally do not qualify), with important exceptions for qualified terminable interest property (QTIP), life estates with a general power of appointment, and life insurance or annuity payments with a power of appointment.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. However, the marital deduction is a cornerstone of estate planning that affects the financial circumstances of surviving spouses.

### §2056A. Qualified domestic trust

This section provides that the marital deduction is allowed for property passing to a surviving spouse who is not a U.S. citizen only if the property passes to or through a qualified domestic trust (QDOT). The section imposes a tax on distributions of corpus from the QDOT and on the remaining trust property at the surviving spouse's death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing, but the QDOT tax on distributions may have income tax implications for the surviving spouse.

### §2058. State death taxes

This section allows a deduction from the gross estate for the amount of any state or District of Columbia estate or inheritance taxes actually paid, for estates of decedents dying after December 31, 2004.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It provides an estate tax deduction for state death taxes paid.

### §2101. Tax imposed

This section imposes the estate tax on the transfer of the taxable estate of every decedent who was a nonresident not a citizen of the United States. The tax is computed using a modified rate schedule, and the taxable estate includes only property situated within the United States.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing for U.S. citizens or residents. It applies to the estates of nonresident aliens.

### §2102. Credits against tax

This section provides credits against the estate tax for nonresident alien decedents, including a unified credit of $13,000 (or a proportional amount if a treaty applies) and credits for foreign death taxes and tax on prior transfers.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing. It provides estate tax credits for nonresident alien decedents.

### §2103. Definition of gross estate

This section defines the gross estate of a nonresident noncitizen decedent as property situated within the United States at the time of death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2104. Property within the United States

This section defines what property is considered situated within the United States for estate tax purposes for nonresident noncitizen decedents, including real and tangible personal property physically present in the U.S., stock of domestic corporations, and certain debt obligations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2105. Property without the United States

This section specifies types of property that are not considered situated within the United States for estate tax purposes, including deposits in U.S. banks, certain portfolio obligations, and property exempt under treaty.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2106. Taxable estate

This section defines the taxable estate of a nonresident noncitizen decedent, allowing deductions for expenses, indebtedness, taxes, losses, charitable transfers, and marital transfers (limited to qualified domestic trusts), proportioned to the U.S.-situs portion of the estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2107. Expatriation to avoid tax

This section imposes a special estate tax regime on certain individuals who lost U.S. citizenship or ceased to be long-term residents with a principal purpose of avoiding U.S. taxes. For such decedents, the gross estate includes certain property outside the U.S. that was previously owned by the decedent.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing but may be relevant to the estate planning of former U.S. citizens or long-term residents.

### §2108. Application of pre-1967 estate tax provisions

This section provides that the estate tax provisions applicable to nonresident noncitizen decedents as they existed before November 14, 1966 continue to apply in cases where a treaty is in effect that references those provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2201. Combat zone-related deaths of members of the Armed Forces, deaths of astronauts, and deaths of victims of certain terrorist attacks

This section provides estate tax relief for members of the Armed Forces who die in combat zones or from combat-zone-related injuries, astronauts who die in the line of duty, and victims of specified terrorist attacks (including September 11, 2001). The estate tax for qualifying decedents is reduced to an amount computed as if the decedent's taxable estate did not exceed $150,000.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing, but it provides significant estate tax relief for qualifying military personnel, astronauts, and terrorism victims.

### §2202. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2203. Definition of executor

This section defines "executor" for estate tax purposes as the executor or administrator of the decedent's estate, or if none is appointed, any person in actual or constructive possession of any property of the decedent.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2204. Discharge of fiduciary from personal liability

This section provides procedures for the fiduciary (executor) to obtain a written discharge from personal liability for estate and gift taxes by filing a written request with the Secretary and receiving a notification of the amount due or a certificate of discharge.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2205. Reimbursement out of estate

This section provides that if the estate tax is paid by an insurance beneficiary, transferee, or surviving tenant, the executor is authorized to recover the tax from the person(s) whose interest is reduced by the payment.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2206. Liability of life insurance beneficiaries

This section provides that unless the decedent's will directs otherwise, the executor may recover from life insurance beneficiaries a proportionate share of the estate tax attributable to the inclusion of the insurance proceeds in the gross estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2207. Liability of recipient of property over which decedent had power of appointment

This section provides that unless the decedent's will directs otherwise, the executor may recover from the recipient of appointive property a proportionate share of the estate tax attributable to inclusion of such property in the gross estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2207A. Right of recovery in the case of certain marital deduction property

This section provides that the estate of a decedent whose gross estate includes QTIP property (section 2044) or surviving spouse's interest property shall be entitled to recover the estate tax attributable to such property from the recipients, unless the decedent's will provides otherwise.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2207B. Right of recovery where decedent retained interest

This section provides a right of recovery for the estate against recipients of property included in the gross estate by reason of section 2036 (retained life estates), unless the decedent's will specifically directs otherwise.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2208. Certain residents of possessions considered citizens of the United States

This section provides that a decedent who was a citizen of a U.S. possession and became a U.S. citizen solely by virtue of their connection with that possession shall be treated as a U.S. citizen for estate tax purposes only if they were domiciled in the United States at the time of death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2209. Certain residents of possessions considered nonresidents not citizens of the United States

This section provides that a decedent who was a citizen of a U.S. possession and became a U.S. citizen solely by virtue of their connection with the possession, and who was not domiciled in the U.S. at death, shall be treated as a nonresident noncitizen for estate tax purposes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2210. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2501. Imposition of tax

This section imposes the federal gift tax on the transfer of property by gift by any individual, whether a citizen, resident, or nonresident. For nonresident noncitizens, the tax applies only to transfers of property situated within the United States. The tax applies whether the transfer is direct or indirect, in trust or otherwise, real or personal, tangible or intangible.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to personal tax filing in that individuals who make gifts exceeding the annual exclusion amount must file a gift tax return (Form 709). While the gift tax is not reported on Form 1040, gift tax liability affects an individual's unified transfer tax credit.

### §2502. Rate of tax

This section provides that the gift tax is computed by applying the unified transfer tax rate schedule (same as the estate tax schedule under section 2001(c)) to cumulative taxable gifts, then subtracting the tax computed on prior period gifts. This creates a progressive tax on the cumulative total of taxable gifts made over the donor's lifetime.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly part of the income tax return, but it determines the gift tax liability reported on Form 709. The gift tax and estate tax share a unified rate schedule.

### §2503. Taxable gifts

This section defines taxable gifts as total gifts made during the calendar year minus the charitable deduction and marital deduction. It provides the annual exclusion ($10,000, as adjusted for inflation) per donee. Transfers for the benefit of a minor under age 21 qualify for the annual exclusion even if the minor's interest is a future interest, as long as certain conditions are met. Transfers for educational or medical expenses paid directly to institutions are not treated as gifts.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who make gifts. The annual exclusion determines which gifts must be reported on Form 709. The exclusions for tuition and medical expenses directly paid to providers are particularly useful for personal tax planning.

### §2504. Taxable gifts for preceding calendar periods

This section provides rules for determining the amount of taxable gifts made in prior calendar periods, taking into account the tax rates and exclusions in effect at the time the gifts were made. This ensures that the progressive rate computation under section 2502 correctly accounts for all prior gifts.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals filing gift tax returns (Form 709), as it governs how prior gifts factor into the current year's gift tax computation.

### §2505. Unified credit against gift tax

This section provides a credit against the gift tax equal to the applicable credit amount (the tentative tax on the basic exclusion amount), reduced by all amounts allowable as credits against the gift tax for preceding calendar periods. This effectively exempts a cumulative total of taxable gifts up to the basic exclusion amount from the gift tax. It is unified with the estate tax credit under section 2010.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals making taxable gifts, as it determines the amount of the unified credit available to offset gift tax on Form 709.

### §2511. Transfers in general

This section provides that the gift tax applies to all transfers of property by gift, whether direct or indirect, and whether in trust or otherwise. It includes special rules for transfers by nonresident noncitizens, limited to property situated within the United States.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section establishes the broad scope of the gift tax, which applies to any individual who transfers property by gift exceeding the annual exclusion.

### §2512. Valuation of gifts

This section provides that if a gift is made in property, the value of the gift is the value of the property at the date of the gift. If property is transferred for less than adequate and full consideration in money or money's worth, the excess of the value over the consideration is a gift.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to anyone who makes gifts, as it determines how the value of the gift is computed for Form 709 reporting.

### §2513. Gift by husband or wife to third party

This section allows spouses to elect to treat gifts made by one spouse to a third party as if made one-half by each spouse ("gift splitting"). Both spouses must consent, and the election applies to all gifts made during the calendar year. This effectively doubles the annual exclusion and the applicable credit amount available for gifts by a married couple.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to married individuals who make gifts, as gift splitting requires both spouses to file a gift tax return (Form 709) for the year.

### §2514. Powers of appointment

This section provides that the exercise or release of a general power of appointment is treated as a transfer of property by the holder of the power for gift tax purposes. A general power of appointment is one exercisable in favor of the holder, the holder's estate, creditors, or creditors of the estate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who hold and exercise or release general powers of appointment, potentially triggering gift tax filing requirements.

### §2515. Treatment of generation-skipping transfer tax

This section provides that any generation-skipping transfer tax imposed on an inter vivos direct skip is treated as a taxable gift for purposes of computing the gift tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who make generation-skipping transfers, as it affects the computation of gift tax on Form 709.

### §2516. Certain property settlements

This section provides that transfers of property between spouses incident to a written agreement in settlement of marital or property rights, where divorce occurs within a specified period, are deemed made for adequate and full consideration and thus are not subject to gift tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals going through a divorce who are making property settlements, as it provides gift tax exemption for qualifying transfers.

### §2515A. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2517. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2518. Disclaimers

This section provides that a qualified disclaimer of an interest in property is treated as if the interest had never been transferred to the disclaiming person. A qualified disclaimer must be irrevocable, in writing, made within 9 months of the transfer, and the disclaiming person must not have accepted the interest or any of its benefits. The disclaimed interest must pass without direction from the disclaiming person to the transferor's spouse or to someone other than the disclaiming person.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who wish to disclaim inherited property, which can affect both gift tax and income tax consequences.

### §2519. Dispositions of certain life estates

This section provides that any disposition of an income interest in a QTIP trust is treated as a transfer of the entire remaining interest in the property for gift tax purposes. This prevents the surviving spouse from divesting the QTIP property without triggering gift tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who are beneficiaries of QTIP trusts and may dispose of their income interest.

### §2521. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2522. Charitable and similar gifts

This section provides an unlimited gift tax deduction for gifts to the United States, states, political subdivisions, the District of Columbia, charitable organizations, religious organizations, fraternal organizations, and veterans' organizations. Special rules apply for gifts of partial interests and split-interest trusts (charitable remainder trusts, charitable lead trusts, pooled income funds).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who make charitable gifts, as it provides a gift tax deduction that may eliminate or reduce gift tax on such transfers.

### §2523. Gift to spouse

This section provides an unlimited marital deduction for gift tax purposes for gifts between spouses who are U.S. citizens. For gifts to a non-citizen spouse, the annual exclusion is limited to a higher amount ($100,000, adjusted for inflation) rather than the unlimited deduction. Special rules apply for QTIP transfers and joint tenancies.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to married individuals making gifts to their spouses. The unlimited marital deduction eliminates gift tax on interspousal transfers when the recipient is a U.S. citizen.

### §2524. Extent of deductions

This section provides that the charitable and marital deductions are applied against the total gifts made during the calendar year, as adjusted, and the resulting net figure becomes the taxable gifts for the period.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to the computation of gift tax on Form 709.

### §2601. Tax imposed

This section imposes a tax on every generation-skipping transfer (GST) at a flat rate equal to the maximum federal estate tax rate (currently 40%). The tax applies to taxable terminations, taxable distributions, and direct skips.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who make or are involved in generation-skipping transfers. The GST tax is reported on Form 709 (for inter vivos transfers) or Form 706 (for transfers at death).

### §2602. Amount of tax

This section provides that the amount of the generation-skipping transfer tax is the taxable amount multiplied by the applicable rate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to the computation of GST tax on Forms 706 and 709.

### §2603. Liability for tax

This section specifies who is liable for the GST tax: the transferee in the case of a taxable distribution, the trustee in the case of a taxable termination, and the transferor in the case of a direct skip (except from a trust, where the trustee is liable).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who are transferors in direct skips or beneficiaries of generation-skipping transfers.

### §2604. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2611. Generation-skipping transfer defined

This section defines a generation-skipping transfer as a taxable distribution, a taxable termination, or a direct skip. It excludes transfers that are already subject to estate or gift tax on the transfer to a non-skip person, and transfers to the extent the property was already subject to GST tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals involved in generation-skipping transfers, as it determines when the GST tax applies.

### §2612. Taxable termination; taxable distribution; direct skip

This section defines the three types of generation-skipping transfers: a taxable termination (termination of an interest in trust property where all remaining interests are held by skip persons), a taxable distribution (distribution from a trust to a skip person that is not a taxable termination or direct skip), and a direct skip (transfer subject to estate or gift tax to a skip person).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who create trusts or make transfers that may constitute generation-skipping transfers.

### §2613. Skip person and non-skip person defined

This section defines a "skip person" as a natural person assigned to a generation two or more generations below the transferor, or a trust in which all interests are held by skip persons. A "non-skip person" is any person who is not a skip person.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to understanding whether the GST tax applies to a particular transfer or trust arrangement.

### §2621. Taxable amount in case of taxable distribution

This section provides that the taxable amount for a taxable distribution is the value of the property received by the transferee, reduced by any expenses incurred in connection with the determination, collection, or refund of the GST tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section may be relevant to individuals who receive distributions from trusts that are subject to GST tax.

### §2622. Taxable amount in case of taxable termination

This section provides that the taxable amount for a taxable termination is the value of all property with respect to which the taxable termination has occurred, reduced by deductions similar to those allowed under section 2053 for estate tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2623. Taxable amount in case of direct skip

This section provides that the taxable amount for a direct skip is the value of the property received by the transferee.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals making direct skips (gifts or bequests to grandchildren or lower generations).

### §2624. Valuation

This section provides that the value of property for GST tax purposes is its fair market value at the time of the generation-skipping transfer, except that in the case of a taxable termination at the same time as the transferor's death, the alternate valuation and special use valuation elections under sections 2032 and 2032A may apply.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to GST tax computations.

### §2631. GST exemption

This section provides every individual with a GST exemption equal to the basic exclusion amount under section 2010(c) (currently aligned with the estate tax exclusion). The exemption may be allocated to transfers to shelter them from the GST tax. Unused GST exemption may be allocated by the individual or by the executor after death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who make generation-skipping transfers, as the GST exemption is allocated on Form 709 or Form 706.

### §2632. Special rules for allocation of GST exemption

This section provides rules for how the GST exemption is allocated, including automatic allocation for direct skips and indirect skips (transfers to trusts that could have GST tax consequences). It allows individuals to opt out of automatic allocation and provides ordering rules for allocations made at or near death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals filing Form 709 who need to allocate or opt out of allocating their GST exemption.

### §2641. Applicable rate

This section provides that the applicable rate of GST tax for a generation-skipping transfer is the product of the maximum federal estate tax rate (40%) and the inclusion ratio with respect to the transfer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to the computation of GST tax.

### §2642. Inclusion ratio

This section defines the inclusion ratio as 1 minus the applicable fraction. The applicable fraction is the amount of GST exemption allocated to the trust or transfer divided by the value of the property transferred, reduced by certain deductions and exclusions. The section includes special rules for charitable lead annuity trusts, estate tax inclusion periods, and qualified severances of trusts.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals and estate planners computing the GST tax or making allocation decisions on Form 709.

### §2651. Generation assignment

This section assigns individuals to generations for GST tax purposes. Lineal descendants of the transferor's grandparents are assigned by the number of generations separating them from the transferor. Non-lineal descendants are assigned by birth date relative to the transferor. Spouses are assigned to the same generation as the individual to whom they are married. A special rule reassigns predeceased-parent descendants to a higher generation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to determining whether a transfer is a generation-skipping transfer.

### §2652. Other definitions

This section defines key terms for the GST tax, including "transferor" (the decedent in the case of property subject to estate tax, or the donor in the case of property subject to gift tax), "trust" (broadly including any arrangement that has substantially the same effect as a trust), and "interest" in a trust.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section provides definitions necessary for computing GST tax.

### §2653. Taxation of multiple skips

This section provides that if there is a generation-skipping transfer of property and immediately after the transfer such property is held in trust, the trust is treated as if the transferor were assigned to the first generation above the highest generation of any person who has an interest in the trust. This "move down" rule prevents cascading GST tax on subsequent generation-skipping transfers from the same trust.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to trustees and beneficiaries of trusts subject to GST tax.

### §2654. Special rules

This section provides special rules for GST tax, including treatment of multiple trusts with substantially separate and independent shares as separate trusts, rules for the inclusion ratio when only a portion of a trust is subject to estate or gift tax, and the basis adjustment for property subject to GST tax at the transferor's death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section may be relevant to individuals receiving property from trusts subject to GST tax, as the basis adjustment rule affects income tax calculations on subsequent dispositions.

### §2661. Administration

This section provides that the GST tax is administered and enforced as if it were imposed by subtitle B (estate and gift taxes), and cross-references the provisions of subtitle F (procedure and administration).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2662. Return requirements

This section requires returns for the GST tax: the transferor files for direct skips (other than from a trust), the trustee files for taxable distributions and taxable terminations, and the executor may file for direct skips at death.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who make generation-skipping transfers and need to understand their filing obligations.

### §2663. Regulations

This section authorizes the Secretary to prescribe regulations for the GST tax, including rules for situations where one or more transfers are part of a series.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing.

### §2664. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant.

### §2701. Special valuation rules in case of transfers of certain interests in corporations or partnerships

This section provides special valuation rules for gift tax purposes when an individual transfers an interest in a corporation or partnership to a family member while retaining a senior equity interest (such as preferred stock or a preferred partnership interest). Under these rules, retained "applicable retained interests" are generally valued at zero, which increases the deemed gift value, unless the retained interest carries qualified payment rights.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals engaged in family business succession planning, as it governs the gift tax valuation of transfers of interests in family-controlled entities.

### §2702. Special valuation rules in case of transfers of interests in trusts

This section provides special valuation rules for gift tax purposes when an individual transfers an interest in a trust to a family member while retaining an interest. Generally, the retained interest is valued at zero for gift tax purposes, increasing the gift value, unless it is a "qualified interest" such as a qualified annuity interest (GRAT) or qualified unitrust interest (GRUT). Special rules apply to personal residence trusts.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who create GRATs, GRUTs, or qualified personal residence trusts as part of estate planning, as it determines the gift tax value of the transfer.

### §2703. Certain rights and restrictions disregarded

This section provides that for estate, gift, and GST tax purposes, the value of property is determined without regard to any option, agreement, right, or restriction to acquire or use the property at less than fair market value, unless certain requirements are met (the arrangement is a bona fide business arrangement, not a device to transfer property for less than adequate consideration, and comparable to arm's-length transactions).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who are parties to buy-sell agreements or other restrictive arrangements affecting the value of business interests for transfer tax purposes.

### §2704. Treatment of certain lapsing rights and restrictions

This section treats certain lapses of voting or liquidation rights in family-controlled entities as transfers for gift or estate tax purposes if the lapse occurs during the holder's life or at death. It also provides that "applicable restrictions" (restrictions on the ability to liquidate an entity that are more restrictive than state law defaults) are disregarded in valuing transferred interests.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who hold interests in family-controlled entities, as lapses of rights can trigger gift or estate tax consequences.

### §2801. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a tax on U.S. citizens and residents who receive covered gifts or bequests from "covered expatriates" (former U.S. citizens or long-term residents who renounced or abandoned their status). The tax rate is the highest estate or gift tax rate (currently 40%) on the value of the covered gift or bequest. Exemptions apply for gifts or bequests that would qualify for the annual exclusion, marital deduction, or charitable deduction.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to U.S. individuals who receive gifts or inheritances from covered expatriates. The recipient must report and pay the tax, which is distinct from both income tax and estate/gift tax.

### §3101. Rate of tax

This section imposes the employee portion of FICA taxes: a 6.2% old-age, survivors, and disability insurance (OASDI) tax on wages up to the Social Security wage base, and a 1.45% hospital insurance (Medicare) tax on all wages. An additional 0.9% Medicare tax applies to wages exceeding $200,000 ($250,000 for joint filers).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing. The FICA taxes withheld from wages appear on Form W-2, and the Additional Medicare Tax may require Form 8959. Excess Social Security tax withheld from multiple employers is claimed as a credit on Form 1040.

### §3102. Deduction of tax from wages

This section requires employers to deduct the employee share of FICA taxes from wages at the time of payment. The employer is liable for payment of the tax whether or not it is actually deducted. Special rules apply for tips.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is indirectly relevant to personal tax filing, as it governs the withholding mechanism that produces the FICA tax amounts shown on Form W-2.

### §3111. Rate of tax

This section imposes the employer portion of FICA taxes: 6.2% for OASDI and 1.45% for Medicare on wages paid to employees. It includes numerous statutory notes about credits for qualified sick leave and family leave wages, paid leave credits, and the employee retention credit enacted during the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, as it imposes the employer share of FICA taxes. However, individuals who are household employers must pay both the employee and employer shares of FICA tax on Schedule H.

### §3112. Instrumentalities of the United States

This section provides that notwithstanding any other provision of law (except the Federal Reserve Act and the Farm Credit Act), all instrumentalities of the United States shall be subject to FICA taxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3121. Definitions

This section provides comprehensive definitions for FICA purposes, including "wages," "employment," "employee," "employer," and "American employer." It includes extensive lists of excluded services and wages, including agricultural labor, domestic service, services for foreign governments, student services, and many others. The section also defines the contribution and benefit base (Social Security wage base) and provides rules for determining what constitutes employment.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to personal tax filing because it determines what income is subject to FICA taxes and thus affects the amounts withheld as shown on Form W-2, as well as the self-employment tax computation.

### §3122. Federal service

This section provides that remuneration for service performed as an employee of the United States or any instrumentality thereof constitutes wages for FICA purposes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing, though it confirms that federal employees are subject to FICA.

### §3123. Deductions as constructive payments

This section provides that if an employer deducts the employee share of FICA tax from an employee's remuneration, the deduction is equivalent to payment of the remuneration to the employee.
