**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3124. Estimate of revenue reduction

This section requires the Secretary to estimate annually the revenue reduction attributable to FICA exclusions for wages paid for domestic service in a private home of the employer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3125. Returns in the case of governmental employees in States, Guam, American Samoa, and the District of Columbia

This section requires states, Guam, American Samoa, the District of Columbia, and their political subdivisions to make FICA returns for employees covered under agreements with the Commissioner of Social Security.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3126. Return and payment by governmental employer

This section provides that each state or political subdivision that has entered into a Social Security coverage agreement shall make returns and pay the required FICA taxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3127. Exemption for employers and their employees where both are members of religious faiths opposed to participation in Social Security Act programs

This section exempts employers and employees from FICA taxes if both are members of a recognized religious sect that is conscientiously opposed to acceptance of social security benefits and that makes reasonable provision for its dependent members. The exemption requires application and approval.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section may be relevant to individuals who are members of qualifying religious sects, as it exempts them from FICA tax (the income would instead be subject to self-employment tax considerations under section 1402(g)).

### §3128. Short title

This section provides that Chapter 21 may be cited as the "Federal Insurance Contributions Act."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3131. Credit for paid sick leave

This section provides eligible employers with a refundable payroll tax credit for qualified sick leave wages paid to employees, enacted as part of the COVID-19 relief legislation. The credit applies to wages paid during specified periods and is subject to various limits and conditions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, as it provides a credit to employers. However, self-employed individuals had analogous credits under separate provisions.

### §3132. Payroll credit for paid family leave

This section provides eligible employers with a refundable payroll tax credit for qualified family leave wages paid to employees, enacted as part of the COVID-19 relief legislation. The credit applies to wages paid during specified periods.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, as it provides a credit to employers.

### §3133. Special rule related to tax on employers

This section provides that the credits allowed under sections 3131 and 3132 shall not be taken into account for purposes of determining the employer's FICA tax liability under section 3111.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3134. Employee retention credit for employers subject to closure due to COVID-19

This section provides eligible employers with a refundable payroll tax credit for qualified wages paid during periods of full or partial suspension of operations due to COVID-19 government orders or significant declines in gross receipts. The credit was generally 70% of qualified wages (up to $10,000 per employee per quarter) for 2021.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing. It provides a credit to employers, though wages on which the credit is claimed may affect an employee's W-2 amounts.

### §3201. Rate of tax

This section imposes the employee portion of the Railroad Retirement Tax, consisting of Tier 1 taxes (equivalent to Social Security and Medicare taxes) and Tier 2 taxes (an additional tax unique to railroad employees) on compensation received by railroad employees.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to railroad employees, whose compensation is subject to railroad retirement taxes rather than FICA. The withheld amounts appear on Form W-2 and affect the individual's tax return.

### §3202. Deduction of tax from compensation

This section requires employers to deduct the employee's share of railroad retirement tax from compensation when paid. The employer is liable for payment whether or not the deduction is made.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is indirectly relevant to railroad employees, as it governs withholding of their railroad retirement taxes.

### §3211. Rate of tax

This section imposes the employee representative (self-employed) portion of the Railroad Retirement Tax on every employee representative, consisting of both the employee and employer equivalent Tier 1 taxes and Tier 2 taxes on compensation for services as an employee representative.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to self-employed railroad employee representatives, who must pay both the employee and employer shares of railroad retirement tax.

### §3212. Determination of compensation

This section provides that for purposes of the Railroad Retirement Tax, the compensation of an employee representative is the compensation received during the calendar year.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to most personal tax filers.

### §3221. Rate of tax

This section imposes the employer portion of the Railroad Retirement Tax, consisting of Tier 1 taxes (equivalent to the employer share of Social Security and Medicare taxes), Tier 2 taxes (the additional railroad-specific tax), and supplemental annuity taxes on compensation paid by employers.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, as it imposes taxes on railroad employers.

### §3231. Definitions

This section provides definitions for the Railroad Retirement Tax Act, including "employer," "employee," "employee representative," "compensation," and "company." It defines who constitutes a railroad employer and employee for purposes of the railroad retirement tax system.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to railroad employees and their tax filing, as it determines whether compensation is subject to railroad retirement tax rather than FICA.

### §3232. Court jurisdiction

This section provides that the district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over civil actions for refund of railroad retirement taxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3233. Short title

This section provides that Chapter 22 may be cited as the "Railroad Retirement Tax Act."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3241. Determination of tier 2 tax rate based on average account benefits ratio

This section establishes the mechanism for determining the Tier 2 tax rate for railroad retirement taxes based on the average account benefits ratio, which reflects the financial condition of the railroad retirement system. The rate for employers ranges from 8.2% to 22.1%, and the rate for employees ranges from 0% to 4.9%.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to railroad employees to the extent it affects the Tier 2 tax rate applied to their compensation.

### §3301. Rate of tax

This section imposes the Federal Unemployment Tax (FUTA) on employers at a rate of 6% on the first $7,000 of wages paid to each employee during the calendar year. Credits are allowed for state unemployment taxes paid, effectively reducing the federal rate to 0.6% for most employers.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, as FUTA is an employer-only tax. However, individuals who are household employers must pay FUTA on Schedule H of Form 1040.

### §3302. Credits against tax

This section provides employers with credits against the FUTA tax for contributions paid to state unemployment funds and for additional credits based on state experience ratings. The section includes rules for successor employers, limits on credits, and special provisions for states with outstanding federal loans.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, though household employers computing FUTA on Schedule H may benefit from these credits.

### §3303. Conditions of additional credit allowance

This section specifies the conditions under which additional credits against FUTA tax are allowed based on reduced state unemployment tax rates due to favorable experience ratings.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3304. Approval of State laws

This section specifies the requirements that state unemployment compensation laws must meet to be approved by the Secretary of Labor for purposes of the FUTA credit. These include requirements for benefit payments, administrative procedures, coverage, and reporting.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3305. Applicability of State law

This section provides rules for determining which state's unemployment compensation law applies to services performed in interstate commerce or across state lines.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3306. Definitions

This section provides comprehensive definitions for FUTA purposes, including "employer," "wages," "employment," "state," "unemployment fund," and "contributions." It includes extensive lists of excluded services and wages, similar to the FICA definitions in section 3121.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section may be relevant to household employers or self-employed individuals who must determine their FUTA obligations. The definitions affect the computation on Schedule H.

### §3307. Deductions as constructive payments

This section provides that employer contributions to a state unemployment fund deducted from an employee's remuneration are treated as payment to the employee.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3308. Instrumentalities of the United States

This section provides that instrumentalities of the United States are subject to FUTA unless specifically exempted.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3309. State law coverage of services performed for nonprofit organizations or governmental entities

This section provides rules for extending state unemployment compensation coverage to employees of nonprofit organizations and state/local government entities, as required for the state's unemployment law to be approved.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3310. Judicial review

This section provides for judicial review of the Secretary of Labor's decisions regarding approval of state unemployment compensation laws.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3311. Short title

This section provides that Chapter 23 may be cited as the "Federal Unemployment Tax Act."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3321. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a tax on each rail employer's taxable period to fund the railroad unemployment insurance system. The tax applies to compensation paid during each calendar quarter.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing, as it imposes a tax on railroad employers.

### §3322. Definitions

This section provides definitions for the Railroad Unemployment Repayment Tax, including "rail employer" and "taxable period."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3401. Definitions

This section provides definitions for income tax withholding purposes, including "wages" (all remuneration for services performed by an employee for an employer, with numerous exceptions), "payroll period," "employee," and "employer." The exceptions from the definition of wages include agricultural labor, domestic service, tips below $20 per month, and many other categories.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing because it determines which payments are subject to income tax withholding, affecting the amounts shown on Form W-2 and the withholding credits on Form 1040.

### §3402. Income tax collected at source

This section is the primary provision governing federal income tax withholding from wages. It requires employers to deduct and withhold income tax from employee wages based on withholding tables or computational procedures prescribed by the Secretary. It provides rules for claiming withholding allowances on Form W-4, voluntary withholding agreements, supplemental wage payments, and withholding on pensions and annuities.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is highly relevant to personal tax filing. It governs the income tax withholding that appears on Form W-2, which is credited against the individual's tax liability on Form 1040. The accuracy of withholding directly affects whether the filer receives a refund or owes additional tax.

### §3403. Liability for tax

This section makes the employer liable for payment of the income tax required to be withheld from wages, and indemnifies the employer against claims for amounts properly withheld.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3404. Return and payment by governmental employer

This section provides that returns of income tax withheld from government employees shall be made by the officer or employee having control of the payment of wages.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3405. Special rules for pensions, annuities, and certain other deferred income

This section provides withholding rules for distributions from pensions, annuities, and other deferred income arrangements. Periodic payments are subject to withholding as if they were wages. Nonperiodic distributions are subject to withholding at a 10% rate. Eligible rollover distributions are subject to mandatory 20% withholding unless directly rolled over. Payees may elect out of withholding on periodic and nonperiodic payments.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing for anyone receiving pension, annuity, or retirement plan distributions. The withholding from these payments is reported on Form 1099-R and credited on Form 1040.

### §3406. Backup withholding

This section requires "backup withholding" at a rate of 24% on certain reportable payments (including interest, dividends, and certain other payments) when the payee fails to furnish a correct taxpayer identification number, the IRS notifies the payor that the TIN is incorrect, or there has been a payee certification failure. The withheld amounts are credited against the payee's income tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing. Individuals subject to backup withholding will see the withheld amounts reported on Forms 1099, and these amounts are credited on Form 1040 as tax payments.

### §3501. Collection and payment of taxes

This section provides that the taxes imposed by chapters 21, 22, 23, and 24 (FICA, railroad retirement, FUTA, and income tax withholding) shall be collected and paid in accordance with the provisions of subtitle F (procedure and administration).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3502. Nondeductibility of taxes in computing taxable income

This section provides that FICA and income tax withholding taxes deducted from an employee's wages shall not be allowed as a deduction to the employee in computing taxable income.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section confirms that FICA taxes withheld from wages are not deductible on the individual's income tax return.

### §3503. Erroneous payments

This section provides that no tax refund for overpayment of employment taxes shall be made to any person if such refund would result in a net payment to that person in excess of the tax actually withheld.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3504. Acts to be performed by agents

This section authorizes designated agents to perform any acts required of employers under the employment tax provisions, including filing returns and paying taxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3505. Liability of third parties paying or providing for wages

This section makes lenders, sureties, or other third parties who supply funds or pay wages liable for the employer's portion of FICA and income tax withholding if the employer fails to pay.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §3506. Individuals providing companion sitting placement services

This section treats individuals who provide companion sitting placement services as employers for FICA and income tax withholding purposes if they regularly provide sitters, receive compensation, and do not place the sitters as employees of the service recipient.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section may be relevant to individuals who operate companion sitting placement services, as it determines their employment tax obligations.

### §3507. Repealed

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This former section related to advance payment of the earned income credit and was repealed in 2010.

### §3508. Treatment of real estate agents and direct sellers

This section provides that qualified real estate agents and direct sellers are treated as non-employees (independent contractors) for federal tax purposes if their services are performed under a written contract providing that they will not be treated as employees and substantially all their compensation is directly related to sales rather than hours worked.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is relevant to individuals who are real estate agents or direct sellers, as it establishes their status as independent contractors for tax purposes, meaning they must pay self-employment tax and report income on Schedule C.

### §3509. Determination of employer's liability for certain employment taxes

This section provides reduced rates of liability for employers who are assessed employment taxes for workers reclassified as employees (from independent contractors) where the employer did not intentionally disregard reporting requirements. The reduced liability is generally 1.5% of wages for income tax withholding and 20% of the employee share of FICA.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is indirectly relevant to individuals who were misclassified as independent contractors and later reclassified as employees, as the reclassification may affect their FICA tax liability and income tax withholding.

### §3510. Coordination of collection of domestic service employment taxes with collection of income taxes

This section provides that domestic service employment taxes (FICA and FUTA on household employees) are reported and paid on the employer's individual income tax return (Schedule H of Form 1040) rather than on quarterly employment tax returns. The threshold for domestic service is wages of $1,000 or more per calendar quarter (for FUTA) or specified per-worker amounts (for FICA, adjusted for inflation).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is directly relevant to personal tax filing for individuals who employ household workers (nannies, housekeepers, etc.). It governs the Schedule H reporting of household employment taxes on Form 1040.

### §3511. Certified professional employer organizations

This section provides rules for certified professional employer organizations (CPEOs), which are entities that enter into service contracts with employers to handle employment tax responsibilities. CPEOs are treated as the employer for federal employment tax purposes with respect to work site employees, and are liable for employment taxes on wages paid to such employees.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal income tax filing, though employees of businesses that use CPEOs will receive W-2s from the CPEO.

### §3512. Treatment of certain persons as employers with respect to motion picture projects

This section allows motion picture project employers to be treated as the employer for federal employment tax purposes with respect to individuals performing services on a motion picture project, even though such individuals may technically be employed by a different entity.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not directly relevant to personal tax filing, though it affects how employment taxes are handled for workers on motion picture projects.

### §4041. Imposition of tax

This section imposes excise taxes on diesel fuel and special motor fuels used in highway vehicles, diesel fuel used in trains, fuel used in inland waterways, and fuel used in noncommercial aviation. The tax rates vary by fuel type and use. Exemptions and reduced rates apply for certain uses, including farming, state and local government use, and use in school buses.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is generally not relevant to personal income tax filing. However, individuals who use diesel fuel or special motor fuels for certain exempt purposes (such as farming) may be eligible to claim a credit or refund of excise taxes paid, which is reported on Form 4136 and carried to Form 1040.

### §4042. Tax on fuel used in commercial transportation on inland waterways

This section imposes an excise tax on fuel used in commercial transportation on specified inland waterways (including the Mississippi River system, the Columbia River system, and others). The tax rate is applied per gallon of fuel consumed.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It applies to commercial waterway transportation operators.

### §4043. Surtax on fuel used in aircraft part of a fractional ownership program

This section imposes a surtax on fuel used in aircraft that are part of a fractional ownership program. The tax is in addition to other fuel taxes and applies to each gallon of fuel used.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It applies to fractional aircraft ownership program managers.

### §4051. Imposition of tax on heavy trucks and trailers sold at retail

This section imposes a 12% excise tax on the first retail sale of heavy highway vehicles (trucks, tractors, and trailers) with a gross vehicle weight exceeding 33,000 pounds (26,000 pounds for tractors). The tax is also imposed on certain parts and accessories installed within six months of the vehicle's first use.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing. It is an excise tax imposed on manufacturers, importers, and retail sellers of heavy trucks and trailers.

### §4052. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions and special rules for the heavy vehicle excise tax under section 4051, including the definition of "first retail sale," rules for calculating the price on which the tax is based, and provisions for installment sales, long-term leases, and the use of a manufacturer's suggested retail price as the tax base.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §4053. Exemptions

This section provides exemptions from the heavy vehicle excise tax for certain vehicles and equipment, including vehicles used for blood collection, mobile machinery, vehicles designed for off-highway use, and idling reduction devices.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** This section is not relevant to personal tax filing.

### §§4061 to 4063. Repealed

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These former sections related to excise taxes on certain automotive parts and accessories and were repealed in 1984.

### §§4001 to 4003. Repealed

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These former sections imposed luxury excise taxes on passenger vehicles, boats, aircraft, jewelry, and furs, and were repealed in 2014.

### [§§4061 to 4063. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly related to taxes on trucks, buses, tractors, articles classified as parts, and exemptions from such taxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1984 and are no longer in effect.

### §4064. Gas guzzler tax

This section imposes an excise tax on the sale by the manufacturer of automobiles that fail to meet certain fuel economy standards. The tax ranges from $0 for vehicles with fuel economy of at least 22.5 miles per gallon up to $7,700 for vehicles rated below 12.5 miles per gallon. The tax applies to 4-wheeled vehicles manufactured primarily for use on public roads and rated at 6,000 pounds unloaded gross vehicle weight or less, with exceptions for emergency vehicles and nonpassenger automobiles.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Generally not directly relevant to individual tax filers. This is a manufacturer-level excise tax imposed at the point of sale by the manufacturer, not a tax paid directly by individual consumers on their tax returns. However, individuals purchasing new gas-inefficient vehicles may see the economic impact reflected in the vehicle's purchase price.

### §4071. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on taxable tires sold by the manufacturer, producer, or importer. The tax rate is 9.45 cents (4.725 cents for biasply tires or super single tires) per 10 pounds of maximum rated load capacity exceeding 3,500 pounds. The tax has a termination date of October 1, 2028.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This is a manufacturer-level excise tax on tire sales that does not appear on individual income tax returns, though it may indirectly affect the price of tires purchased by consumers.

### §4072. Definitions

This section provides definitions for terms used in the tire excise tax provisions, including "taxable tire," "rubber," "tires of the type used on highway vehicles," "biasply tire," and "super single tire." A taxable tire is one used on highway vehicles that is wholly or partly made of rubber and marked for highway use.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a definitional section supporting the manufacturer-level tire excise tax and has no bearing on individual tax returns.

### §4073. Exemptions

This section provides that the tire excise tax imposed by section 4071 does not apply to tires sold for the exclusive use of the Department of Defense or the Coast Guard.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This exemption applies only to government purchases and has no bearing on individual tax returns.

### §4081. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on taxable fuels (gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene) upon their removal from a refinery or terminal, entry into the United States, or sale to an unregistered person. The tax rates are 18.3 cents per gallon for gasoline, 19.3 cents for aviation gasoline, and 24.3 cents for diesel fuel or kerosene, plus an additional 0.1 cent per gallon for the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund. Special rates apply for aviation fuel used in commercial aviation. The general rates are scheduled to decrease to 4.3 cents per gallon after September 30, 2028.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant as a line item on individual tax returns. However, this tax is embedded in the price of gasoline and diesel fuel that individuals purchase. Certain individuals may be eligible for credits or refunds of these fuel taxes under sections 6420, 6421, or 6427 (e.g., farmers using gasoline for farming purposes or fuel used for certain nontaxable purposes).

### §4082. Exemptions for diesel fuel and kerosene

This section provides exemptions from the fuel tax imposed by section 4081 for diesel fuel and kerosene that is destined for nontaxable use, indelibly dyed by mechanical injection, and meets certain marking requirements. Nontaxable uses include uses exempt from section 4041(a)(1) tax, use in trains, and certain other specified uses. Additional exceptions to dyeing requirements exist for kerosene used as non-fuel feedstock and for wholesale distributors.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individual filers. This section primarily governs fuel distribution and taxation at the wholesale level. However, individuals who purchase dyed (tax-exempt) diesel fuel for off-highway uses such as farming or home heating may benefit from these exemptions indirectly.

### §4083. Definitions; special rule; administrative authority

This section defines key terms for the fuel excise tax provisions, including "taxable fuel" (gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene), "gasoline," "diesel fuel," and "commercial aviation." It also provides that the use of taxable fuel (other than in producing taxable fuels) is considered a removal and therefore subject to tax. The section grants the Secretary administrative authority to inspect fuel storage facilities and records.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual tax returns. These are definitional and administrative provisions that support the fuel excise tax system.

### §4084. Cross references

This section provides cross references to other Code provisions that relieve purchasers of gasoline and other taxable fuels from excise tax in certain circumstances, including section 6420 (farm use), section 6421 (certain nonhighway purposes), and section 6427 (nontaxable purposes).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Marginally relevant. The cross-referenced sections (particularly section 6420 for farmers and section 6421 for nonhighway gasoline use) can provide credits or refunds to individual taxpayers who use fuel for qualifying purposes. These are claimed on Form 4136.

### §4101. Registration and bond

This section requires certain persons involved in the production, importation, or distribution of taxable fuels, biodiesel, alcohol, sustainable aviation fuel, and second generation biofuel to register with the Secretary. It also authorizes the Secretary to require bonds and liens as conditions of registration, and provides for denial, revocation, or suspension of registration. The section includes information reporting requirements for registered persons.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individual filers. This section governs registration requirements for businesses involved in fuel production and distribution.

### §4102. Inspection of records by local officers

This section permits state and local officers charged with enforcement or collection of fuel taxes to inspect records required to be kept under the fuel excise tax provisions, under regulations prescribed by the Secretary.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is an administrative provision concerning intergovernmental tax enforcement cooperation.

### §4103. Certain additional persons liable for tax where willful failure to pay

This section provides that officers, employees, or agents who willfully fail to assure payment of fuel excise taxes, or who willfully cause taxpayers to fail to pay such taxes, shall be jointly and severally liable with the taxpayer for those taxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a penalty and liability provision applicable to persons involved in fuel tax collection, not to individual income tax filers.

### §4104. Information reporting for persons claiming certain tax benefits

This section requires persons claiming tax benefits under sections 34, 40, 40A, 4041(b)(2), 6426, or 6427(e) to file returns providing information about such benefits. The Secretary prescribes the manner and content of such returns to ensure proper administration of fuel-related tax benefits.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant for individuals who claim fuel tax credits (such as the credit for federal tax paid on fuels under section 34), as they may be required to file information returns in connection with those claims.

### §4105. Two-party exchanges

This section provides that in a two-party exchange of taxable fuel between registered persons at a terminal, the delivering person is not liable for the excise tax. Instead, the receiving person (who removes the fuel across the terminal rack) bears the tax liability. The transaction must meet specific requirements including written contract and terminal operator record-keeping.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs fuel distribution transactions between registered fuel businesses and has no bearing on individual tax returns.

### §4121. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on coal from mines located in the United States sold by the producer. The rate is $1.10 per ton for coal from underground mines and $0.55 per ton for coal from surface mines, with a cap of 4.4 percent of the sale price. The tax does not apply to lignite. Revenue from this tax funds the Black Lung Disability Trust Fund.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a producer-level excise tax on coal sales that does not appear on individual tax returns.

### §4131. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax of 75 cents per dose on any taxable vaccine sold by the manufacturer, producer, or importer. If a vaccine is described in more than one category, the amounts are summed. The revenue funds the Vaccine Injury Compensation Trust Fund.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This is a manufacturer-level excise tax on vaccines that does not appear on individual tax returns, though it may be reflected in the price of vaccinations.

### §4132. Definitions and special rules

This section defines "taxable vaccine" to include vaccines containing diphtheria toxoid, tetanus toxoid, pertussis antigens, and vaccines against measles, mumps, rubella, polio, HIB, hepatitis A and B, chicken pox, rotavirus, streptococcus pneumoniae, seasonal influenza, meningococcal disease, and human papillomavirus. It also provides rules for credit or refund when vaccines are returned or destroyed, and other special rules.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a definitional section supporting the vaccine excise tax and does not affect individual tax returns.

### §4161. Imposition of tax

This section imposes excise taxes on sporting goods. A 10 percent tax applies to sport fishing equipment sold by manufacturers (with a $10 cap on fishing rods and poles, and a 3 percent rate for electric outboard motors and tackle boxes). An 11 percent tax applies to bows with peak draw weight of 30 pounds or more and archery equipment, and a 39-cent per shaft tax (adjusted for inflation) applies to certain arrow shafts. These taxes fund wildlife conservation programs.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. These are manufacturer-level excise taxes on sporting goods that do not appear on individual tax returns, though they affect retail prices of fishing and archery equipment.

### §4162. Definitions; treatment of certain resales

This section defines "sport fishing equipment" to include fishing rods and poles, reels, lines, spears, terminal tackle, fishing supplies and accessories, tip-ups, rod belts, and electric outboard motors. It also provides anti-avoidance rules for resales to related persons, treating the related person as the manufacturer for tax purposes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a definitional section for the sporting goods excise tax that has no bearing on individual tax returns.

### [§§4171 to 4173. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly imposed taxes on cameras, camera lenses, photographic film, and projectors.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1965 and are no longer in effect.

### §4181. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a manufacturer's excise tax on firearms and ammunition: 10 percent on pistols and revolvers, and 11 percent on other firearms, shells, and cartridges. Revenue from this tax funds wildlife conservation through the Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This is a manufacturer-level excise tax that does not appear on individual tax returns, though it is reflected in the retail price of firearms and ammunition.

### §4182. Exemptions

This section provides exemptions from the firearms and ammunition excise tax for firearms on which the National Firearms Act tax (section 5811) has been paid, firearms purchased by the military with appropriated funds, and small manufacturers or importers who produce or import fewer than 50 such articles per calendar year. It also provides that firearms dealers are not required to record purchaser information for shotgun ammunition and common rifle ammunition.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These exemptions apply to manufacturers, military purchasers, and dealers, not to individual taxpayers filing personal returns.

### §4216. Definition of price

This section defines how the sales price is determined for purposes of computing manufacturer excise taxes under chapter 32. It addresses the treatment of containers, packing, and transportation charges, and provides constructive sale price rules when articles are sold at retail, on consignment, or between related parties. It also covers partial payments under leases and installment sales, and provides rules for excluding local advertising charges from the taxable sale price.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs price determinations for manufacturer excise taxes and does not apply to individual tax returns.

### §4217. Leases

This section provides that the lease of an article by the manufacturer, producer, or importer is treated as a sale for manufacturer excise tax purposes. It includes rules limiting the total tax payable on lease payments, provides rules for sales before and after the total tax becomes payable, and contains special provisions for leases of automobiles subject to the gas guzzler tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs the treatment of manufacturer leases for excise tax purposes and has no bearing on individual tax returns.

### §4218. Use by manufacturer or importer considered sale

This section provides that if a manufacturer, producer, or importer uses an article (other than certain tires) rather than selling it, the use is treated as a sale and the person is liable for the applicable excise tax. Special rules apply for tires and for coal. The tax is computed based on the price at which similar articles are sold in the ordinary course of trade.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section addresses manufacturer-level excise tax liability and does not affect individual tax returns.

### §4219. Application of tax in case of sales by other than manufacturer or importer

This section provides that if a person acquires from a manufacturer the right to sell an article through a nontaxable transaction or by operation of law, that person's sale of the article is taxable as if made by the manufacturer, and the person is liable for the excise tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a specialized manufacturer excise tax provision that does not affect individual tax returns.

### [§§4220 to 4225. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly related to exemptions for sales or resales to manufacturers and other related provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1958 and are no longer in effect.

### §4221. Certain tax-free sales

This section provides exemptions from manufacturer excise taxes for articles sold for further manufacture, export, use as supplies for vessels or aircraft, exclusive use by state or local governments, exclusive use by nonprofit educational organizations, and exclusive use by qualified blood collector organizations. Various limitations apply depending on the specific tax involved.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs exemptions from manufacturer excise taxes and does not apply to individual income tax returns.

### §4222. Registration

This section requires manufacturers, first purchasers, and second purchasers to be registered under this section for the tax-free sale provisions of section 4221 to apply. Exceptions are provided for state and local government purchases, certain export transactions, and supplies for vessels or aircraft. The Secretary may deny, revoke, or suspend registration if it is used to avoid tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This registration requirement applies to businesses involved in manufacturing and distribution, not to individual taxpayers.

### §4223. Special rules relating to further manufacture

This section provides that a manufacturer who purchases an article tax-free for further manufacture under section 4221(a)(1) is treated as the manufacturer of that article for excise tax purposes. It includes rules for computing the tax when the article is subsequently sold or used, allowing the manufacturer to elect certain price bases for tax computation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs further-manufacture excise tax rules applicable to businesses, not individuals.

### [§4224. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. It formerly provided exemptions for articles taxable as jewelry.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section was repealed in 1965 and is no longer in effect.

### §4225. Exemption of articles manufactured or produced by Indians

This section provides that no manufacturer excise tax shall be imposed on any article of native Indian handicraft manufactured or produced by Indians on Indian reservations, in Indian schools, or by Indians under federal jurisdiction in Alaska.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This exemption applies to the manufacture and sale of Indian handicrafts and does not affect individual income tax returns.

### [§4226. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. It formerly related to floor stocks taxes on tires, tread rubber, and gasoline.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section was repealed in 1976 and is no longer in effect.

### §4227. Cross reference

This section provides a cross reference to section 7871, which provides exemptions for sales to Indian tribal governments (or their subdivisions) for their exclusive use.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross reference provision related to tribal government exemptions from excise taxes.

### [§§4231 to 4234. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly imposed taxes on admissions to entertainment events, cabarets, and related activities.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1965 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4241 to 4243. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly imposed taxes on dues and membership fees for social, athletic, or sporting clubs.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1965 and are no longer in effect.

### §4251. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a 3 percent excise tax on amounts paid for communications services, including local telephone service, toll telephone service, and teletypewriter exchange service. The tax is paid by the person paying for the services. Special rules address prepaid telephone cards, treating the face amount as the taxable amount paid when the card is transferred by a telecommunications carrier.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Indirectly relevant. Individual taxpayers pay this tax as part of their telephone bills. The tax appears as a line item on phone bills but does not require any action on individual tax returns. Certain exempt organizations and government entities are exempt from this tax.

### §4252. Definitions

This section defines key terms for the communications excise tax: "local telephone service" (access to a local telephone system and telephonic communication), "toll telephone service" (varying-charge telephonic communications or periodic-charge unlimited communications outside the local area), "teletypewriter exchange service" (access to a teletypewriter exchange system), and "private communication service" (exclusive or priority channel use).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions supporting the communications excise tax and do not require action on individual tax returns.

### §4253. Exemptions

This section provides various exemptions from the communications excise tax, including exemptions for certain coin-operated service under 25 cents, news services, international organizations and the Red Cross, servicemen in combat zones, common carriers and communications companies, installation charges, nonprofit hospitals, state and local governments, nonprofit educational organizations, and qualified blood collector organizations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Marginally relevant. Individual servicemen in combat zones benefit from the exemption for toll telephone service originating in a combat zone. Most other exemptions apply to organizations rather than individuals.

### §4254. Computation of tax

This section provides rules for computing the communications excise tax, specifying that the tax base is the sum of all charges for services included in the bill. It allows grouping of items for computation purposes and provides that tax on toll telephone service paid by coin in coin-operated phones is rounded to the nearest multiple of 5 cents. State and local taxes separately stated on the bill are excluded from the tax base.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. While individuals pay this tax through their phone bills, no action is required on individual tax returns.

### §4261. Imposition of tax

This section imposes excise taxes on air transportation of persons: 7.5 percent of the amount paid for taxable transportation, plus a per-segment domestic tax of $3.00 for each domestic segment (adjusted for inflation), plus a $12.00 international departure/arrival tax for flights beginning or ending in the United States. Special rules apply for transportation to and from Alaska and Hawaii, and for flights between the continental U.S. and rural airports.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Indirectly relevant. Individual taxpayers pay these taxes as part of their airfare when purchasing airline tickets. The taxes appear as line items on airline tickets and receipts but do not require action on individual tax returns.

### §4262. Definition of taxable transportation

This section defines "taxable transportation" for purposes of the air transportation excise tax as transportation by air that begins and ends within the United States or the 225-mile zone, or the domestic portion of other air transportation that is not part of uninterrupted international air transportation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a definitional provision supporting the air transportation excise tax system.

### §4263. Special rules

This section provides special rules for the air transportation excise tax, including rules for payments made outside the U.S. for prepaid orders, tax deductions upon refunds, payment of tax by carriers when tax is not collected from passengers, application of tax to domestic payments, treatment of round trips, and treatment of transportation outside the northern portion of the Western Hemisphere.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. These rules govern how the air transportation excise tax is collected and administered.

### §4271. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a 6.25 percent excise tax on amounts paid for taxable transportation of property by air. The tax applies only to amounts paid to persons engaged in the business of transporting property by air for hire. The tax is paid by the person making the payment, with special rules for payments made outside the United States.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individuals. This tax applies to commercial air freight shipments and would primarily affect businesses. Individuals shipping packages by air freight would pay this tax indirectly through shipping charges.

### §4272. Definition of taxable transportation, etc.

This section defines "taxable transportation" for air freight tax purposes as air transportation that begins and ends in the United States, with exceptions for certain international and export transportation. Excess baggage accompanying passengers on established airlines is excluded from the definition of "property."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a definitional provision for the air freight excise tax.

### §4281. Small aircraft on nonestablished lines

This section provides that air transportation excise taxes (sections 4261 and 4271) do not apply to transportation by aircraft with a maximum certificated takeoff weight of 6,000 pounds or less, unless the aircraft is operated on an established line or is a jet aircraft. Sightseeing flights are not considered operation on an established line.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Marginally relevant. Individuals using small charter aircraft or sightseeing flights may benefit from this exemption, as the air transportation taxes would not apply to such flights.

### §4282. Transportation by air for other members of affiliated group

This section provides that no air transportation excise tax is imposed when one member of an affiliated group of corporations pays another member for the use of an aircraft owned or leased by a group member, provided the aircraft is not available for hire by non-group members. Availability for hire is determined on a flight-by-flight basis.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This exemption applies to intercompany transactions within corporate affiliated groups.

### [§§4286, 4287. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly imposed a tax on the use of safety deposit boxes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1965 and are no longer in effect.

### §4291. Cases where persons receiving payment must collect tax

This section requires every person receiving payment for facilities or services subject to excise tax under chapter 33 (communications and air transportation taxes) to collect the amount of tax from the person making such payment, except as otherwise provided for prepaid orders for air transportation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This is a collection requirement imposed on service providers (telephone companies, airlines), not on individual taxpayers.

### §4293. Exemption for United States and possessions

This section authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to exempt articles or services purchased for the exclusive use of the United States from excise taxes imposed under sections 4041, 4051, chapter 32 (other than sections 4064 and 4121), and subchapter B of chapter 33, where such taxes would cause substantial burden that could be avoided by the exemption.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This exemption applies to government purchases and does not affect individual tax returns.

### [§§4294, 4295. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections were repealed in 1976.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

### §4371. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on policies of insurance, indemnity bonds, annuity contracts, and reinsurance policies issued by foreign insurers or reinsurers. The rates are 4 cents per dollar of premium for casualty insurance and indemnity bonds, 1 cent per dollar for life, sickness, and accident insurance and annuity contracts, and 1 cent per dollar for reinsurance.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individuals. This tax is imposed on insurance issued by foreign insurers and is paid by the person making, signing, or issuing the document. However, individuals purchasing casualty or life insurance from foreign insurers may bear the economic burden of this tax.

### §4372. Definitions

This section defines terms for the foreign insurance excise tax, including "foreign insurer or reinsurer" (nonresident alien, foreign partnership, or foreign corporation), "policy of casualty insurance," "indemnity bond," "insured" (domestic entities or foreign entities doing business in the U.S. with respect to U.S. hazards), and "policy of reinsurance."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions supporting the foreign insurance excise tax.

### §4373. Exemptions

This section provides exemptions from the foreign insurance excise tax for amounts effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business (unless exempt under a treaty) and for indemnity bonds required to secure payment of pensions, allowances, or other payments by the United States.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These exemptions apply to specific types of insurance transactions and government-related bonds.

### §4374. Liability for tax

This section provides that the foreign insurance excise tax is paid on the basis of a return by any person who makes, signs, issues, or sells the taxable documents, or for whose benefit they are made. The United States and its agencies are not liable for the tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant in rare cases. An individual who purchases insurance directly from a foreign insurer could be the person liable for paying this tax.

### §4375. Health insurance

This section imposes a fee on each specified health insurance policy for each policy year ending after September 30, 2012. The fee equals $2 (adjusted for health care spending increases) multiplied by the average number of lives covered under the policy. The fee is paid by the issuer of the policy. Specified health insurance policy includes accident or health insurance policies issued for individuals residing in the United States, with exceptions for policies covering only excepted benefits.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This fee is paid by insurance issuers, not by individual policyholders, though it may be reflected in insurance premiums. The fee funds the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Trust Fund.

### §4376. Self-insured health plans

This section imposes a fee on applicable self-insured health plans for each plan year ending after September 30, 2012. The fee equals $2 (adjusted for health care spending increases) multiplied by the average number of lives covered under the plan. The fee is paid by the plan sponsor (typically the employer or employee organization).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This fee is paid by plan sponsors, not by individual participants in self-insured health plans.

### §4377. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions and special rules for the fees on health insurance and self-insured health plans, including definitions of "accident and health coverage," "insurance policy," and "United States." It provides that governmental entities are treated as persons subject to the fee, and that the fee terminates for policy or plan years ending after September 30, 2029.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional and administrative provisions for the health plan fees.

### §4401. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on wagers: 0.25 percent for wagers authorized under state law, and 2 percent for unauthorized wagers. The tax base includes all charges incident to placing the wager. Each person engaged in the business of accepting wagers or conducting wagering pools or lotteries is liable for the tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individuals. This tax is imposed on persons in the business of accepting wagers, not on individual bettors. However, individuals engaged in bookmaking or accepting wagers would be liable for this tax. Note that gambling winnings are separately reportable as income on individual tax returns.

### §4402. Exemptions

This section exempts from the wagering excise tax wagers placed with state-licensed parimutuel enterprises, wagers placed in coin-operated devices, and wagers placed in state-conducted lotteries, sweepstakes, or wagering pools.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These exemptions apply to the business of accepting wagers, not to individual bettors.

### §4403. Record requirements

This section requires each person liable for the wagering excise tax to keep a daily record showing the gross amount of all wagers on which they are liable, in addition to all other records required by section 6001(a).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This record-keeping requirement applies to persons in the wagering business, not to individual bettors.

### §4404. Territorial extent

This section limits the wagering excise tax to wagers accepted in the United States, or placed by a person in the United States with a U.S. citizen or resident, or in a wagering pool or lottery conducted by a U.S. citizen or resident.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This defines the territorial scope of the wagering excise tax on businesses accepting wagers.

### §4405. Cross references

This section provides cross references to sections 4421 through 4423 and subtitle F for penalties and administrative provisions applicable to the wagering excise tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference provision for the wagering excise tax.

### §4411. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a special annual occupational tax of $500 on each person liable for the wagering excise tax or engaged in receiving wagers for such a person. A reduced rate of $50 per year applies to persons whose liability is determined only under state-authorized wagers and to those receiving wagers on their behalf.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This occupational tax applies to persons in the business of accepting wagers, not to individual bettors.

### §4412. Registration

This section requires each person liable for the wagering occupational tax to register with the IRS, providing their name and place of residence and the name and place of residence of each person for whom they receive wagers.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This registration requirement applies to persons in the wagering business.

### §4413. Certain provisions made applicable

This section makes certain provisions applicable to the wagering occupational tax provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a technical provision for the wagering occupational tax.

### §4414. Cross references

This section provides cross references to other relevant provisions for the wagering occupational tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference provision.

### §4421. Definitions

This section provides definitions for the wagering tax provisions, including the definition of "wager" and "lottery."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These definitions support the wagering excise and occupational tax provisions.

### §4422. Applicability of Federal and State laws

This section provides that payment of the wagering taxes does not exempt any person from penalties under federal or state law for engaging in wagering.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This clarifies that wagering tax compliance does not legalize otherwise illegal gambling.

### §4423. Inspection of books

This section provides rules regarding the inspection of records maintained under the wagering tax provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is an administrative provision for the wagering tax.

### §4424. Disclosure of wagering tax information

This section provides rules governing the disclosure and use of wagering tax information, including limitations on its admissibility in non-tax-related proceedings and provisions for sharing with state tax officials.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs the confidentiality and disclosure of wagering tax information.

### §4461. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a harbor maintenance tax on the value of commercial cargo loaded on or unloaded from vessels using U.S. ports. The tax rate is 0.125 percent of the value of the cargo.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax applies to commercial cargo operations at ports and does not affect individual tax returns.

### §4462. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions and special rules for the harbor maintenance tax, including definitions of "port use," "commercial cargo," and rules for determining the value of cargo.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the harbor maintenance tax.

### §4471. Imposition of tax

This section imposes a $3 per passenger tax on covered voyages (commercial transportation of passengers for entertainment or recreation between U.S. ports, or from a U.S. port that returns to the same or another U.S. port). This is commonly known as the cruise ship passenger tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Indirectly relevant. Individual cruise passengers pay this tax as part of their cruise fare, but it does not require action on individual tax returns.

### §4472. Definitions

This section provides definitions for the cruise ship passenger tax, including "covered voyage" and "passenger vessel."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the cruise passenger tax.

### §4475. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on certain international voyages, specifically on transportation by water of passengers between the United States and points in the Caribbean, or on cruises departing from and returning to the United States.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. Like the general cruise passenger tax, this is collected as part of cruise fares and does not require action on individual returns.

### §4481. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an annual excise tax on the use of certain highway motor vehicles with a taxable gross weight of 55,000 pounds or more. The tax ranges from $100 to $550 per year depending on the vehicle's weight. The tax applies during a period from July 1 through June 30 and does not apply after September 30, 2028.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Generally not relevant to most individuals. This tax applies to heavy commercial vehicles and is paid on Form 2290. Individuals who own and operate heavy trucks for business purposes would be subject to this tax.

### §4482. Definitions

This section defines key terms for the heavy vehicle use tax, including "highway motor vehicle," "taxable gross weight," and "State." A highway motor vehicle is one designed for highway transportation with a taxable gross weight of at least 55,000 pounds.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the heavy vehicle use tax.

### §4483. Exemptions

This section provides exemptions from the heavy vehicle use tax for vehicles used by state and local governments, the United States, the American National Red Cross, Indian tribal governments, mass transportation authorities, and certain vehicles used 5,000 miles or less (7,500 miles for farm vehicles). It also exempts vehicles used by certain blood collector organizations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant in limited cases. Individual farmers operating heavy vehicles used 7,500 miles or less may qualify for the agricultural vehicle exemption.

### §4484. Cross references

This section provides cross references to other provisions relevant to the heavy vehicle use tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference provision.

### [§§4491 to 4494. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections formerly imposed taxes related to certain transportation of persons.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1982 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4495 to 4498. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect. These sections were repealed in 1997.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

### §4501. Repurchase of corporate stock

This section imposes a 1 percent excise tax on the fair market value of stock repurchased by certain publicly traded corporations during the taxable year. The tax is reduced by the fair market value of any stock issued during the year, including stock issued to employees. The tax applies to repurchases after December 31, 2022, and does not apply where total repurchases do not exceed $1 million.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual tax returns. This tax is imposed on corporations, not individuals. However, individual shareholders of publicly traded companies may be indirectly affected to the extent the tax influences corporate decisions regarding stock buybacks versus dividends.

### [§§4531, 4532. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4541, 4542. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4551 to 4553. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4561, 4562. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4571, 4572. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4581, 4582. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4591 to 4597. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1976 and are no longer in effect.

### [§§4601 to 4603. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These sections were repealed in 1962 and are no longer in effect.

### §4611. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on domestic crude oil received at a U.S. refinery and on imported petroleum products entered into the United States for consumption or use. The tax funds the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund and the Hazardous Substance Superfund. The Hazardous Substance Superfund financing rate is 16.4 cents per barrel (adjusted for inflation), and the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund rate is 9 cents per barrel.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax is imposed on refiners and importers of petroleum products and does not appear on individual tax returns.

### §4612. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions and special rules for the petroleum excise tax, including definitions of "crude oil," "domestic crude oil," and "petroleum product." It also provides rules for the application of the tax and its termination dates.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the petroleum excise tax.

### §4661. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on certain chemicals (such as acetylene, benzene, butane, chlorine, methane, and many others) sold by the manufacturer, producer, or importer. The tax rates vary by chemical and are specified in a table within the section. The tax funds the Hazardous Substance Superfund.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a manufacturer-level excise tax on chemical substances that does not affect individual tax returns.

### §4662. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions and special rules for the chemical excise tax, including exemptions for chemicals used as fuel, in the production of fertilizer, for export, and for certain other uses. It also defines key terms such as "manufacturer" and provides rules for methane and butane.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the chemical excise tax.

### §4671. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on taxable substances (certain imported chemical substances) sold or used by the importer. The tax amount is determined based on the chemicals used in the manufacture of the substance, with the purpose of equalizing the tax burden with domestically produced substances taxed under section 4661.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is an importer-level excise tax on imported chemical substances.

### §4672. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions for the imported substance excise tax, including the definition of "taxable substance" and rules for determining which substances are subject to the tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the imported chemical substance excise tax.

### §4681. Imposition of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on ozone-depleting chemicals sold or used by the manufacturer, producer, or importer. The tax equals a base tax amount multiplied by the ozone-depleting factor for the chemical.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a manufacturer-level excise tax on ozone-depleting chemicals.

### §4682. Definitions and special rules

This section provides definitions and special rules for the ozone-depleting chemicals excise tax, including the list of ozone-depleting chemicals and their ozone-depleting factors, the base tax amount, and various exemptions (such as for chemicals used as feedstocks or exported).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional and administrative provisions for the ozone-depleting chemicals excise tax.

### §4701. Tax on issuer of registration-required obligation not in registered form

This section imposes a tax of 1 percent of the principal amount on the issuer of any registration-required obligation that is not in registered form. The tax is paid by the issuer at the time of issuance.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This tax applies to issuers of debt obligations and encourages the use of registered (rather than bearer) bonds.

### §4901. Payment of tax

This section provides that payment of special (occupational) taxes shall be evidenced by a stamp or other documentation as the Secretary may prescribe.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs payment procedures for special occupational taxes.

### §4902. Liability of partners

This section provides that any number of persons doing business in partnership at one location are required to pay only one special tax for that location.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This provision applies to partnerships liable for special occupational taxes.

### §4903. Liability in case of business in more than one location

This section provides that a person liable for a special tax who carries on business at more than one location must pay the special tax at each location.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This provision applies to businesses with multiple locations that are subject to special occupational taxes.

### §4904. Liability in case of different businesses of same ownership and location

This section provides that a person who carries on different businesses at the same location may be liable for separate special taxes for each business.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This applies to businesses subject to multiple special occupational taxes.

### §4905. Liability in case of death or change of location

This section provides rules for the continuation of special tax stamps in the event of death of the taxpayer or a change in business location.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This applies to special occupational tax administrative matters.

### §4906. Application of State laws

This section provides that payment of federal special occupational taxes does not exempt any person from penalties under state law.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This clarifies the relationship between federal and state occupational tax requirements.

### §4907. Federal agencies or instrumentalities

This section provides that no tax under subchapters B and C of chapter 36 (wagering taxes) shall be assessed against or collected from certain agencies or instrumentalities of the United States.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This exempts certain federal entities from wagering-related taxes.

### §4911. Tax on excess expenditures to influence legislation

This section imposes a 25 percent excise tax on the excess lobbying expenditures of certain tax-exempt organizations that have elected to be subject to the lobbying expenditure limits of section 501(h). Excess lobbying expenditures are the greater of the amount by which total lobbying expenditures exceed the lobbying nontaxable amount, or the amount by which grass roots lobbying expenditures exceed the grass roots nontaxable amount.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax applies to tax-exempt organizations, not to individuals.

### §4912. Tax on disqualifying lobbying expenditures of certain organizations

This section imposes a 5 percent excise tax on the lobbying expenditures of organizations that lose their tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) by reason of making disqualifying lobbying expenditures. The tax is also imposed on the managers who agreed to such expenditures.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax applies to tax-exempt organizations and their managers.

### §4940. Excise tax based on investment income

This section imposes a 1.39 percent excise tax on the net investment income of private foundations. Net investment income includes gross investment income (interest, dividends, rents, royalties) and capital gain net income, reduced by expenses attributable to such income. Certain exempt operating foundations are not subject to this tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual tax returns. However, individuals who are substantial contributors to or managers of private foundations should be aware of this tax's impact on foundation operations.

### §4941. Taxes on self-dealing

This section imposes a two-tier excise tax on acts of self-dealing between a private foundation and a disqualified person. The initial tax is 10 percent of the amount involved per year on the self-dealer and 5 percent on foundation managers who knowingly participated. If not corrected, additional taxes of 200 percent on the self-dealer and 50 percent on the manager apply. Self-dealing includes sales, leases, loans, compensation, and transfers of foundation assets to disqualified persons.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who are disqualified persons with respect to a private foundation (substantial contributors, foundation managers, family members, etc.) can be personally liable for this tax if they engage in self-dealing transactions.

### §4942. Taxes on failure to distribute income

This section imposes a 30 percent excise tax on the undistributed income of a private foundation that is not distributed for charitable purposes by the end of the following taxable year. If the undistributed income is not corrected, an additional 100 percent tax applies. The minimum distribution amount is generally 5 percent of the foundation's assets.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual tax returns. This tax is imposed on private foundations, though individuals involved in foundation management should be aware of distribution requirements.

### §4943. Taxes on excess business holdings

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax on the excess business holdings of a private foundation in any business enterprise. Excess business holdings generally exist when the combined holdings of the foundation and disqualified persons exceed 20 percent of the voting stock. A 200 percent additional tax applies if excess holdings are not disposed of within a correction period.
