**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual returns. However, individuals who are disqualified persons should be aware that their holdings are aggregated with foundation holdings for purposes of determining excess business holdings.

### §4944. Taxes on investments which jeopardize charitable purpose

This section imposes a 10 percent initial tax on investments by private foundations that jeopardize the carrying out of their exempt purposes. A 5 percent tax is imposed on foundation managers who knowingly participated. Additional taxes of 25 percent on the foundation and 5 percent on managers apply if the investment is not removed from jeopardy.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Foundation managers who are individuals can be personally liable for the 5 percent tax if they knowingly approve jeopardizing investments.

### §4945. Taxes on taxable expenditures

This section imposes a 20 percent initial tax on taxable expenditures by private foundations, including lobbying, electioneering, grants to individuals not meeting certain requirements, grants to non-public charities without expenditure responsibility, and expenditures for non-charitable purposes. A 5 percent tax is imposed on foundation managers who agree to such expenditures. Additional taxes apply if not corrected.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Foundation managers who are individuals can be personally liable for the manager-level tax if they agree to taxable expenditures.

### §4946. Definitions and special rules

This section defines key terms for the private foundation excise taxes, including "disqualified person" (substantial contributors, foundation managers, owners of more than 20% of a substantial contributor, family members of disqualified persons, and certain related entities), "foundation manager," and "member of the family."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Relevant for individuals who may be classified as disqualified persons with respect to a private foundation, as this status affects their potential liability under sections 4941 through 4945.

### §4947. Application of taxes to certain nonexempt trusts

This section extends certain private foundation excise tax rules to charitable trusts that are not exempt under section 501(a) but that have amounts dedicated to charitable purposes. Split-interest trusts (such as charitable remainder trusts) are subject to the self-dealing and taxable expenditure rules.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who are beneficiaries of or contributors to charitable trusts or charitable remainder trusts should be aware that these private foundation rules may apply to such trusts.

### §4948. Application of taxes and denial of exemption with respect to certain foreign organizations

This section provides rules for applying the private foundation excise taxes to foreign organizations, including provisions for denial of tax exemption to foreign private foundations that engage in prohibited transactions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This applies to foreign organizations and their interactions with the U.S. tax system.

### §4951. Taxes on self-dealing

This section imposes excise taxes on acts of self-dealing between a black lung benefit trust and a disqualified person, similar to the private foundation self-dealing rules. The initial tax is 10 percent of the amount involved on the disqualified person and 2.5 percent on trust managers who participate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This applies to black lung benefit trusts and their disqualified persons.

### §4952. Taxes on taxable expenditures

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax on taxable expenditures by black lung benefit trusts, with a 2.5 percent tax on trust managers. Taxable expenditures include amounts paid for non-trust purposes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This applies to black lung benefit trusts.

### §4953. Tax on excess contributions to black lung benefit trusts

This section imposes a 5 percent excise tax on excess contributions to a black lung benefit trust, payable by the contributor. Excess contributions are amounts in excess of the deduction allowable under section 192.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This applies to contributors (typically coal mine operators) to black lung benefit trusts.

### §4955. Taxes on political expenditures of section 501(c)(3) organizations

This section imposes a 10 percent initial tax on political expenditures by section 501(c)(3) organizations, with a 2.5 percent tax on organization managers who agree to such expenditures. If not corrected, additional taxes of 100 percent on the organization and 50 percent on managers apply. Political expenditures include amounts paid in connection with participation in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for public office.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who are managers of 501(c)(3) organizations can be personally liable for the 2.5 percent (or 50 percent) tax if they agree to prohibited political expenditures.

### §4958. Taxes on excess benefit transactions

This section imposes excise taxes on excess benefit transactions between a tax-exempt organization described in section 501(c)(3) or 501(c)(4) and a disqualified person. The initial tax on the disqualified person is 25 percent of the excess benefit, with a 200 percent additional tax if not corrected. Organization managers who knowingly participate face a 10 percent tax (up to $20,000 per transaction). An excess benefit transaction occurs when the economic benefit to the disqualified person exceeds the value of consideration received by the organization.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Relevant. Individuals who are disqualified persons (such as officers, directors, or persons with substantial influence over an exempt organization) can be personally liable for these taxes. This would need to be reported on Form 4720.

### §4959. Taxes on failures by hospital organizations

This section imposes a $50,000 excise tax on a hospital organization for each failure to meet the community health needs assessment requirements of section 501(r)(3) during the applicable taxable year.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax applies to hospital organizations, not to individuals.

### §4960. Tax on excess tax-exempt organization executive compensation

This section imposes a 21 percent excise tax on remuneration in excess of $1 million paid to any covered employee by an applicable tax-exempt organization, and on any excess parachute payment paid to such an employee. Covered employees are the organization's five highest-compensated employees. The tax is paid by the employer organization.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individuals, as the tax is imposed on the employer organization. However, highly compensated employees of tax-exempt organizations should be aware that their compensation above $1 million triggers this tax on their employer.

### §4961. Abatement of second tier taxes where there is correction

This section provides for the abatement of second-tier (additional) excise taxes imposed under chapter 42 (private foundation taxes, etc.) if the taxable event is corrected during the correction period.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who are liable for second-tier taxes under chapter 42 (e.g., as disqualified persons or foundation managers) can obtain abatement by timely correcting the taxable event.

### §4962. Abatement of first tier taxes in certain cases

This section provides for the abatement of first-tier excise taxes imposed under chapter 42 if the taxable event was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect, and is corrected within the correction period.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who inadvertently trigger first-tier taxes under chapter 42 may seek abatement by demonstrating reasonable cause and making timely corrections.

### §4963. Definitions

This section defines "first tier tax," "second tier tax," "taxable event," "correct" and "correction period" for purposes of the abatement provisions in sections 4961 and 4962. The correction period begins on the date the taxable event occurs and ends 90 days after a notice of deficiency.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Relevant for individuals subject to chapter 42 excise taxes, as it defines the timeframes for correcting taxable events to obtain abatement.

### §4965. Excise tax on certain tax-exempt entities entering into prohibited tax shelter transactions

This section imposes excise taxes on tax-exempt entities that are parties to "prohibited tax shelter transactions" (listed transactions or substantially similar transactions). For entities other than plans, the tax is the highest rate times the entity's net income or proceeds from the transaction. Entity managers who approve such transactions face a $20,000 tax per transaction.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who serve as managers of tax-exempt entities and approve prohibited tax shelter transactions can be personally liable for the $20,000 per-transaction tax.

### §4966. Taxes on taxable distributions

This section imposes a 20 percent excise tax on taxable distributions from donor advised funds, payable by the sponsoring organization. Fund managers who knowingly approve taxable distributions face a 5 percent tax (up to $10,000). A taxable distribution is any distribution from a donor advised fund to a natural person, or to any other person unless the distribution is for a charitable purpose.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individuals who serve as fund managers of sponsoring organizations and knowingly approve taxable distributions from donor advised funds can be personally liable for the manager-level tax.

### §4967. Taxes on prohibited benefits

This section imposes a 125 percent excise tax on any donor, donor advisor, or related person who receives a prohibited benefit from a donor advised fund. Fund managers who knowingly approve the benefit face a 10 percent tax (up to $10,000).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Relevant. Individual donors or donor advisors who receive prohibited benefits (such as more than incidental benefits) from a donor advised fund are personally liable for the 125 percent tax on the amount of the benefit.

### §4968. Excise tax based on investment income of private colleges and universities

This section imposes a 1.4 percent excise tax on the net investment income of applicable educational institutions -- private colleges and universities with at least 500 tuition-paying students, more than 50 percent of which are in the United States, and with assets (other than those used in the institution's exempt function) of at least $500,000 per student.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax applies to certain large private educational institutions, not to individual taxpayers.

### §4971. Taxes on failure to meet minimum funding standards

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax (or 100 percent in certain cases) on the accumulated funding deficiency of pension plans that fail to meet the minimum funding requirements of sections 412 and 430. The tax is imposed on the employer responsible for contributing to the plan. A 100 percent additional tax applies if the deficiency is not corrected within a taxable period.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individuals. This tax applies to employers sponsoring defined benefit pension plans. However, self-employed individuals who sponsor defined benefit plans could potentially be subject to this tax if they fail to make required contributions.

### §4972. Tax on nondeductible contributions to qualified employer plans

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax on nondeductible contributions to qualified employer plans, section 403(b) plans, and SEPs. Nondeductible contributions are amounts contributed that exceed the deduction limits under section 404. The tax is imposed on the employer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Self-employed individuals who make contributions to their own qualified plans in excess of the deductible limits may be subject to this 10 percent excise tax on the excess contributions.

### §4973. Tax on excess contributions to certain tax-favored accounts and annuities

This section imposes a 6 percent excise tax on excess contributions to IRAs (traditional and Roth), Coverdell education savings accounts, Archer MSAs, health savings accounts, and ABLE accounts. The tax is imposed on the individual account holder for each year the excess contribution remains in the account.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Highly relevant. Individual taxpayers who make excess contributions to any of these accounts are subject to this 6 percent annual tax until the excess is withdrawn. This is reported on Form 5329, which is filed with the individual's Form 1040. Common situations include contributing more than the annual IRA limit or contributing to a Roth IRA when income exceeds the eligibility threshold.

### §4974. Excise tax on certain accumulations in qualified retirement plans

This section imposes a 25 percent excise tax (reduced to 10 percent in some cases) on the amount by which the minimum required distribution from a qualified retirement plan, IRA, or similar account exceeds the actual amount distributed during the calendar year. The tax applies when an individual fails to take required minimum distributions after reaching the applicable age.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Highly relevant. Individual taxpayers who fail to take required minimum distributions from their retirement accounts are subject to this excise tax. This is a common issue for retirees and is reported on Form 5329. The tax can be substantial -- 25 percent of the shortfall amount.

### §4975. Tax on prohibited transactions

This section imposes excise taxes on prohibited transactions between a plan (including IRAs, qualified retirement plans, and other tax-favored accounts) and a disqualified person. The initial tax is 15 percent of the amount involved per year, with a 100 percent additional tax if the transaction is not corrected. Prohibited transactions include sales, leases, loans, transfers of plan assets, and provision of services between the plan and a disqualified person.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Highly relevant. Individual IRA owners who engage in prohibited transactions with their IRA (such as borrowing from the IRA, using IRA funds as collateral, or engaging in transactions with disqualified persons) are subject to these excise taxes. The prohibited transaction can also result in the IRA being treated as fully distributed. This is reported on Form 5329.

### §4976. Taxes with respect to funded welfare benefit plans

This section imposes a 100 percent excise tax on disqualified benefits provided under a funded welfare benefit plan (as described in section 419). Disqualified benefits include post-retirement medical or life insurance benefits provided through a welfare benefit fund and certain other benefits that exceed allowable limits.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individuals. This tax applies to employers who fund welfare benefit plans with excess contributions.

### §4977. Tax on certain fringe benefits provided by an employer

This section imposes a 30 percent excise tax on excess fringe benefits provided to highly compensated employees if the employer elects to apply special nondiscrimination rules. The tax applies only to pre-1989 fringe benefit programs.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is an employer-level tax on certain fringe benefits and applies only to legacy programs.

### §4978. Tax on certain dispositions by employee stock ownership plans and certain cooperatives

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax on the amount realized when an ESOP or cooperative disposes of employer securities acquired in a section 1042 transaction within 3 years after the acquisition, if the total number of allocated shares decreases below a specified level.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This tax is imposed on the ESOP or cooperative employer, not on individual participants.

### §4979. Tax on certain excess contributions

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax on excess contributions and excess aggregate contributions to cash or deferred arrangements (401(k) plans) that are not corrected within 2.5 months after the end of the plan year. The tax is imposed on the employer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. While individual employees may have excess 401(k) contributions returned to them, the excise tax itself is imposed on the employer.

### §4979A. Tax on certain prohibited allocations of qualified securities

This section imposes a 50 percent excise tax on certain prohibited allocations of employer securities in an ESOP or S corporation ESOP. The tax applies when securities are allocated to disqualified persons in violation of section 409(p).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to most individuals. The tax is imposed on the employer or the S corporation, though disqualified persons may be affected by the underlying allocation rules.

### §4980. Tax on reversion of qualified plan assets to employer

This section imposes a 20 percent excise tax (or 50 percent in certain cases) on the amount of any employer reversion from a qualified plan upon termination. The 50 percent rate applies unless the employer establishes a qualified replacement plan or provides benefit increases to plan participants equal to at least 20 percent of the reversion amount.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to individual tax filers. This tax is imposed on employers who receive reversions of surplus assets from terminated pension plans.

### §4980B. Failure to satisfy continuation coverage requirements of group health plans

This section imposes an excise tax on employers who fail to satisfy the COBRA (Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act) group health plan continuation coverage requirements. The tax is generally $100 per day for each day in the noncompliance period for each qualified beneficiary affected. Maximum and minimum tax amounts and various exceptions and waivers are provided.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual tax filers, as this tax is imposed on employers. However, individuals who are qualified beneficiaries under COBRA benefit from the enforcement of these requirements.

### §4980C. Requirements for issuers of qualified long-term care insurance contracts

This section imposes an excise tax on issuers of qualified long-term care insurance contracts that fail to meet certain consumer protection requirements. The tax is $100 per insured for each day the failure continues.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This tax is imposed on insurance issuers, not on individual policyholders. However, individuals purchasing long-term care insurance benefit from these consumer protection requirements.

### §4980D. Failure to meet certain group health plan requirements

This section imposes an excise tax on group health plans and health insurance issuers that fail to meet certain requirements under chapter 100, including portability, nondiscrimination, mental health parity, and other mandates. The tax is generally $100 per day per individual affected, with various exceptions for certain small employers and specific circumstances.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individuals, as this tax is imposed on employers and insurers. However, individuals benefit from the enforcement of group health plan requirements.

### §4980E. Failure of employer to make comparable Archer MSA contributions

This section imposes an excise tax on employers who fail to make comparable Archer MSA contributions for all comparable participating employees. The tax equals 35 percent of the aggregate amount contributed to Archer MSAs during the calendar year.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This tax is imposed on employers, not on individual Archer MSA holders.

### §4980F. Failure of applicable plans reducing benefit accruals to satisfy notice requirements

This section imposes an excise tax on plan administrators who fail to provide required advance notice (generally 45 days) before implementing a significant reduction in the rate of future benefit accrual under a defined benefit or money purchase pension plan. The tax is $100 per day per participant or alternate payee not notified.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individuals. This tax is imposed on plan administrators. However, individuals who are plan participants benefit from the requirement of advance notice of benefit reductions.

### §4980G. Failure of employer to make comparable health savings account contributions

This section imposes an excise tax on employers who fail to make comparable HSA contributions for all comparable participating employees. The tax equals 35 percent of the aggregate amount contributed by the employer to HSAs during the calendar year. Special rules apply for employees covered under a high-deductible health plan through a cafeteria plan.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This tax is imposed on employers, not on individual HSA holders.

### §4980H. Shared responsibility for employers regarding health coverage

This section imposes an excise tax (the "employer shared responsibility payment") on applicable large employers (generally 50 or more full-time employees) that fail to offer minimum essential coverage to substantially all full-time employees and their dependents, or that offer coverage that is not affordable or does not provide minimum value. The monthly tax is either $2,000 per full-time employee (minus the first 30) or $3,000 per full-time employee receiving a premium tax credit, whichever is less.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant to individual tax returns. This tax is imposed on large employers. However, it is related to the individual marketplace -- when employees receive premium tax credits because employer coverage is inadequate, it triggers employer liability.

### §4981. Excise tax on undistributed income of real estate investment trusts

This section imposes a 4 percent excise tax on the excess of the required distribution over the distributed amount for a REIT during a calendar year. The required distribution is generally 85 percent of the REIT's ordinary income, 95 percent of capital gain net income, and any undistributed amounts from prior years.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This tax is imposed on REITs, not on individual REIT shareholders. However, individual REIT investors benefit from the distribution requirements that this tax enforces.

### §4982. Excise tax on undistributed income of regulated investment companies

This section imposes a 4 percent excise tax on the excess of the required distribution over the distributed amount for a regulated investment company (mutual fund) during a calendar year. The required distribution is generally 98 percent of ordinary income and 98.2 percent of capital gain net income.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not directly relevant. This tax is imposed on mutual funds, not on individual fund shareholders. However, individual investors benefit from the distribution requirements that this tax enforces, as mutual funds typically make year-end distributions to avoid this tax.

### §4985. Stock compensation of insiders in expatriated corporations

This section imposes a 20 percent excise tax on the value of specified stock compensation held by insiders (officers, directors, and 10-percent-or-more shareholders) of corporations that undergo a corporate inversion (expatriation). The tax applies to stock options, restricted stock, and other stock-based compensation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant. Individual corporate insiders who hold specified stock compensation in a corporation that undergoes an inversion transaction are subject to this 20 percent excise tax on the value of such compensation.

### §4999. Golden parachute payments

This section imposes a 20 percent nondeductible excise tax on excess parachute payments received by disqualified individuals in connection with a change in corporate ownership or control. This tax is in addition to regular income tax and applies to the portion of parachute payments that exceeds the individual's base amount (average annualized compensation for the five preceding years). A parachute payment is generally a payment contingent on a change in corporate control that equals or exceeds three times the base amount.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Highly relevant for affected individuals. Corporate executives and other highly compensated individuals who receive golden parachute payments in connection with a corporate change of control are personally liable for this 20 percent excise tax on the excess amount. This is reported on the individual's tax return.

### §5000. Certain group health plans

This section imposes a tax on certain group health plans of large employers (20+ employees) that fail to comply with COBRA secondary payer requirements with respect to end-stage renal disease patients and individuals entitled to Medicare benefits by reason of disability.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax is imposed on employer group health plans.

### §5000A. Requirement to maintain minimum essential coverage

This section originally required most individuals to maintain minimum essential health coverage or pay a shared responsibility payment (the individual mandate). The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 reduced the shared responsibility payment to $0 for months beginning after December 31, 2018, effectively eliminating the penalty while leaving the mandate in place.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Historically relevant but effectively moot for tax years after 2018. While the provision still technically exists in the Code, the penalty for not having health coverage has been reduced to zero at the federal level. Some states have enacted their own individual mandates. For tax years 2014-2018, this was reported on the individual's Form 1040.

### §5000B. Imposition of tax on indoor tanning services

This section imposes a 10 percent excise tax on amounts paid for indoor tanning services (using ultraviolet lamps to tan the skin). The tax is collected by the person providing the service and is paid quarterly. It does not apply to phototherapy services performed by licensed medical professionals.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Indirectly relevant. Individual consumers pay this 10 percent tax when they use indoor tanning services, but it does not require any action on individual tax returns. The tax is collected and remitted by the tanning salon or provider.

### §5000C. Imposition of tax on certain foreign procurement

This section imposes a 2 percent excise tax on the amount paid to any foreign person pursuant to a contract with the U.S. government for the provision of goods manufactured or produced, or services provided, in a country that is not party to an international procurement agreement with the United States. The tax is collected by withholding.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant to most individuals. This tax applies to foreign persons receiving payments under U.S. government contracts.

### §5000D. Designated drugs during noncompliance periods

This section imposes an excise tax on the sale of designated drugs by manufacturers, producers, or importers during periods of noncompliance with Medicare drug price negotiation requirements under the Inflation Reduction Act. The tax rate increases over time during the noncompliance period, starting at 186 percent and potentially reaching 1,900 percent of the drug price.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This tax is imposed on pharmaceutical manufacturers during noncompliance periods and does not appear on individual tax returns.

### §5001. Imposition, rate, and attachment of tax

This section imposes an excise tax on all distilled spirits produced in or imported into the United States. The general rate is $13.50 per proof gallon, with reduced rates for certain small distillers (the first 100,000 proof gallons at $2.70 per proof gallon for eligible distillers). The tax attaches as soon as the substance is in existence as a distilled spirit.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a producer/importer-level excise tax on distilled spirits.

### §5002. Definitions

This section provides definitions for terms used in the distilled spirits excise tax provisions, including "distilled spirits," "proof spirits," "proof gallon," "distiller," "processor," "bonded premises," and numerous other terms.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are definitional provisions for the distilled spirits excise tax.

### §5003. Cross references to exemptions, etc.

This section provides cross references to various exemptions and special provisions applicable to the distilled spirits excise tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These are cross-reference provisions for the distilled spirits excise tax.

### §5004. Lien for tax

This section provides that the excise tax on distilled spirits is a first lien on the spirits from the time of production until the tax is paid, and establishes lien requirements for distillery premises and equipment.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs tax liens related to distilled spirits production.

### §5005. Persons liable for tax

This section establishes the persons liable for the distilled spirits excise tax, including the distiller or importer, the proprietor of a bonded premises, and any person in possession of spirits not bearing evidence of tax payment.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This applies to persons in the distilled spirits business.

### §5006. Determination of tax

This section provides rules for determining the amount of the distilled spirits excise tax, including provisions for the determination of proof and quantity.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs the mechanics of computing the distilled spirits tax.

### §5007. Collection of tax on distilled spirits

This section provides rules for the collection of excise tax on distilled spirits, including the timing of tax payment upon removal from bonded premises.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs the collection of the distilled spirits excise tax.

### §5008. Abatement, remission, refund, and allowance for loss or destruction of distilled spirits

This section provides rules for abatement, remission, refund, or allowance of the excise tax on distilled spirits that are lost or destroyed, including losses during production, storage, and transportation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This governs tax relief for distilled spirits losses.

### §5010. Credit for wine content and for flavors content

This section provides a credit against the distilled spirits excise tax for wine and flavors content in the distilled spirits. The credit reduces the tax to reflect the lower tax rates that would otherwise apply to the wine and flavors if taxed separately.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a producer-level excise tax credit.

### §5011. Income tax credit for average cost of carrying excise tax

This section provides an income tax credit for small domestic distillers equal to the amount of interest that would accrue on the average tax-determined inventory of distilled spirits at a prescribed rate. This credit effectively compensates small distillers for the carrying cost of excise taxes during the aging process.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Potentially relevant for individuals who operate small distilleries as sole proprietors, as they could claim this income tax credit on their individual returns.

### [§§5021 to 5026. Repealed]

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes recordkeeping requirements on wine premises operators.

### §5368. Gauging and marking

This section requires all wine and wine spirits to be locked, sealed, gauged, and appropriately marked, branded, labeled, or identified as prescribed by the Secretary. Wines must be removed in containers bearing marks and labels evidencing compliance.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns the identification and marking of wine for excise tax purposes.

### §5369. Inventories

This section requires each proprietor of premises subject to the wine provisions to take and report inventories as prescribed by the Secretary.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes inventory requirements on wine premises operators.

### §5370. Losses

This section provides that no tax shall be collected on wines lost or destroyed while in bond, except in cases of theft (unless it occurred without connivance or negligence) or voluntary destruction (unless done under government supervision or with proper notice and approval).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs excise tax relief for wine losses.

### §5371. Insurance coverage, etc.

This section limits any remission, abatement, refund, or credit of taxes on wines or wine spirits to the extent that the claimant is not already indemnified or recompensed for the tax.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns insurance limitations on excise tax relief for wine.

### §5372. Sampling

This section allows wine in any bonded wine cellar to be utilized for testing, tasting, or sampling free of tax, under regulations prescribed by the Secretary.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns tax-free wine sampling at bonded wine cellars.

### §5373. Wine spirits

This section defines wine spirits authorized for use in wine production as brandy or wine spirits produced exclusively from fresh or dried fruit, wine residues, or special natural wine. It governs the withdrawal, use, transfer, and credit of wine spirits, and allows distillates containing aldehydes to be used in fermentation of wine for distilling material.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs the production and use of wine spirits in winemaking.

### §5381. Natural wine

This section defines "natural wine" as the product of the juice or must of sound, ripe grapes or other fruit, made with authorized cellar treatment and containing not more than 21 percent total solids by weight. Wine that becomes substandard is not considered natural wine unless the condition is corrected.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides a technical definition used in wine excise tax regulation.

### §5382. Cellar treatment of natural wine

This section defines proper cellar treatment of natural wine, including historical and newly developed practices for correcting or stabilizing wine or fruit juice. It enumerates specifically authorized treatments such as use of concentrated juice, addition of wine spirits, amelioration and sweetening, and addition of volatile fruit-flavor concentrate.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs technical winemaking treatments for excise tax classification purposes.

### §5383. Amelioration and sweetening limitations for natural grape wines

This section sets limits on the sweetening of grape wines after fermentation and the amelioration of high-acid grape wines. It specifies the maximum total solids content, alcoholic content, and volume of ameliorating materials that may be used in producing these wines.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns technical wine production limitations for excise tax purposes.

### §5384. Amelioration and sweetening limitations for natural fruit and berry wines

This section sets limits on the addition of sugar and ameliorating materials to natural wines made from fruits and berries other than grapes. It provides separate rules for wines produced with and without amelioration and specifies maximum total solids content, sugar quantities, and volume limits for ameliorating materials.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns technical fruit wine production limitations for excise tax purposes.

### §5385. Specially sweetened natural wines

This section defines specially sweetened natural wines as products made by adding sugar or juice to natural wine to produce a finished product with total solids content exceeding 17 percent and alcoholic content of not more than 14 percent. It governs blending and cellar treatment of such wines and prohibits the addition of wine spirits.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides technical definitions for a category of wine under excise tax law.

### §5386. Special natural wines

This section defines special natural wines as products made from a natural wine base with the addition of natural herbs, spices, fruit juices, aromatics, and other flavorings, produced pursuant to a formula approved by the Secretary. No added spirits (other than those in the base wine or approved essences) may be used.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section defines a category of wine for excise tax classification purposes.

### §5387. Agricultural wines

This section provides that wines made from agricultural products other than fruit juice shall be made in accordance with good commercial practice as prescribed by the Secretary, classified as "standard agricultural wines." No wine spirits, coloring material, or flavoring material (except hops in honey wine) may be added, and wines from different agricultural commodities may not be blended.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns technical agricultural wine production rules for excise tax purposes.

### §5388. Designation of wines

This section governs the designation of wines for sale, requiring standard wines to be marked with their proper designation as to kind and origin, and other wines to be designated in a manner that adequately describes their true composition and distinguishes them from standard wines. It includes detailed rules for the use of semi-generic wine designations such as Burgundy, Champagne, and Sherry.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns wine labeling and designation for excise tax and consumer protection purposes.

### §5391. Exemption from distilled spirits taxes

This section exempts bonded wine cellar proprietors from distilled spirits taxes on wine spirits used in wine production on their premises. However, if wine or wine spirits are used in violation of the subchapter, the applicable tax under section 5001 shall be collected unless the proprietor shows the violation was not knowing.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides an excise tax exemption for wine producers using wine spirits.

### §5392. Definitions

This section defines key terms used throughout the wine provisions, including "standard wine," "heavy bodied blending wine," "pure sugar," "total solids," "same kind of fruit," "own production," and "liquid sugar."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides technical definitions for wine excise tax regulation.

### §5401. Qualifying documents

This section requires every brewer to file a notice and execute a bond with the Secretary before commencing or continuing business. The bond is conditioned on payment of beer tax, compliance with export provisions, and faithful observance of all beer production and sale requirements. Certain small breweries may be exempt from bond requirements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs the bonding and notice requirements for breweries.

### §5402. Definitions

This section defines "brewery" as the land and buildings described in the brewer's notice, with requirements for continuity of the premises (except where separated by public passageways or similar dividers). The Secretary may approve nearby facilities for case packing, loading, or storing as part of the brewery.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides technical definitions for brewery regulation.

### §5403. Cross references

This section provides cross references to the Secretary's authority to disapprove brewers' bonds (section 5551), require installation of meters and apparatus (section 5552), and provisions for depositing U.S. bonds in lieu of sureties.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference section within brewery regulation provisions.

### §5411. Use of brewery

This section restricts the use of brewery premises to producing, packaging, and storing beer, cereal beverages, vitamins, ice, malt, malt syrup, byproducts, and soft drinks, as well as processing spent grain, carbon dioxide, and yeast. The Secretary may authorize other purposes that will not jeopardize revenue.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs permitted uses of brewery premises.

### §5412. Removal of beer in containers or by pipeline

This section provides that beer may be removed from a brewery for consumption or sale only in hogsheads, packages, and similar containers bearing required marks and labels, except for transfers under section 5414 or by pipeline to contiguous distilled spirits plants.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs beer removal from breweries.

### §5413. Brewers procuring beer from other brewers

This section allows a brewer to obtain beer from another brewer in containers marked with the purchasing brewer's name and address, with taxpayment to be made by the producer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns inter-brewery beer procurement.

### §5414. Transfer of beer between bonded facilities

This section allows beer to be removed from one brewery to another without payment of tax and mingled with beer at the receiving brewery, subject to conditions prescribed by the Secretary. Qualifying transfers include those between breweries of the same brewer, between related corporations, and between independent breweries where the transferor divests all interest and the transferee accepts tax responsibility.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs beer transfers between breweries.

### §5415. Records and returns

This section requires every brewer to keep records and make returns of operations and transactions in the form, at the times, and for the periods prescribed by the Secretary. Records must be preserved and available for inspection by internal revenue officers during business hours.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes recordkeeping requirements on brewers.

### §5416. Definitions of package and packaging

This section defines "package" as a bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container, and "packaging" as the filling of any package.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides definitions for brewery packaging regulation.

### §5417. Pilot brewing plants

This section authorizes the Secretary to permit the establishment of pilot brewing plants off brewery premises for research, analytical, experimental, or development purposes. This does not waive any bond or tax payment requirements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns experimental brewing facilities.

### §5418. Beer imported in bulk

This section allows beer imported in bulk containers to be transferred to brewery premises without payment of internal revenue tax. The brewery proprietor becomes liable for the tax upon release from customs custody, relieving the importer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs customs and excise tax treatment of imported beer.

### §5501. Establishment

This section authorizes the establishment of vinegar plants using the vaporizing process, where distilled spirits of not more than 15 percent alcohol by volume are produced exclusively for use in vinegar manufacture on the premises.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns the establishment of vinegar plants.

### §5502. Qualification

This section requires vinegar plant operators to apply to the Secretary for registration and permission to operate before commencing business, with applications in the form prescribed by the Secretary containing information about the applicant, premises, and operations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns qualification requirements for vinegar plants.

### §5503. Construction and equipment

This section requires vinegar plants to be constructed and equipped in accordance with regulations prescribed by the Secretary.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs construction requirements for vinegar plants.

### §5504. Operation

This section allows vinegar manufacturers to separate distilled spirits from mash and condense the vapor into water or other liquid used in making vinegar. It prohibits removal of fluid containing more than 2 percent proof spirits and requires recordkeeping of materials, production, and removals.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs the operations of vinegar plants.

### §5505. Applicability of provisions of this chapter

This section specifies which general provisions of the distilled spirits chapter apply to vinegar plants, including tax provisions, prohibited premises rules, entry and examination rights, still registration, meter installation, officer assignment, and penalty provisions. Most other provisions of the chapter do not apply to vinegar plants.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section addresses the applicability of distilled spirits rules to vinegar plants.

### §5511. Establishment and operation

This section exempts volatile fruit-flavor concentrate plants from most provisions of the distilled spirits chapter, provided the concentrate contains no more alcohol than reasonably unavoidable, is rendered unfit for beverage use before removal (or transferred to a bonded wine cellar), and the manufacturer complies with prescribed requirements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns volatile fruit-flavor concentrate plants.

### §5512. Control of products after manufacture

This section provides a cross reference to section 5001(a)(6) for the applicability of all distilled spirits laws to volatile fruit-flavor concentrates sold, transported, or used in violation of law.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference provision for fruit-flavor concentrate regulation.

### [§§5521 to 5523. Repealed]

These sections have been repealed and are no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. These repealed sections formerly related to manufacturing bonded warehouses.

### §5551. General provisions relating to bonds

This section requires bonds to be approved by the Secretary of the Treasury before any person may commence or continue business as a distiller, warehouseman, processor, brewer, or winemaker. Bonds may be disapproved based on prior convictions for fraud or felony relating to alcohol. During qualifying periods, certain taxpayers are exempt from bond requirements for operations involving distilled spirits, wines, or beer for nonindustrial use.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs bond requirements for alcohol industry businesses.

### §5552. Installation of meters, tanks, and other apparatus

This section authorizes the Secretary to require the installation of meters, tanks, pipes, or other apparatus at distilled spirits plants, breweries, and other premises for revenue protection. The cost is borne by the person on whose premises the installation is required. Refusal to install means the person cannot conduct business.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns revenue protection equipment at alcohol production facilities.

### §5553. Supervision of premises and operations

This section authorizes the Secretary to assign internal revenue officers to premises established under the alcohol chapter and defines the term "internal revenue officer assigned to the premises."

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns government supervision of alcohol production premises.

### §5554. Pilot operations

This section authorizes the Secretary to waive regulatory provisions of the alcohol chapter for temporary pilot or experimental operations to facilitate development of improved governmental supervision methods. Bond and tax payment requirements may not be waived.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns pilot operations for distilled spirits regulation improvement.

### §5555. Records, statements, and returns

This section requires every person liable for any tax imposed by the alcohol chapter to keep records, render statements, and make returns as prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary may permit unified recordkeeping systems for brewery operations and may waive record requirements when they no longer serve a necessary purpose. Photographic or electronic reproductions may be retained in lieu of originals.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes general recordkeeping requirements on persons subject to alcohol excise taxes.

### §5556. Regulations

This section authorizes the Secretary to make distinctions in regulatory requirements based on differences in materials or methods used in production, processing, or storage of distilled spirits.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns the Secretary's rulemaking authority for distilled spirits regulation.

### §5557. Officers and agents authorized to investigate, issue search warrants, and prosecute for violations

This section requires the Secretary to investigate violations of the alcohol subtitle and report prosecutable violations to U.S. Attorneys. Officers may swear out warrants before U.S. magistrate judges and conduct committing trial prosecutions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns law enforcement for alcohol excise tax violations.

### §5558. Authority of enforcement officers

This section provides a cross reference to section 7608 for provisions relating to the authority of internal revenue enforcement officers.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference for enforcement officer authority.

### §5559. Determinations

This section authorizes the Secretary to make quantitative determinations required or authorized by the alcohol chapter through actual count, weight, measurement, statistical methods, or other prescribed means.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns measurement methods for alcohol excise tax purposes.

### §5560. Other provisions applicable

This section extends all provisions of Subtitle F (Procedure and Administration) to the alcohol subtitle, insofar as applicable and not inconsistent.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section extends general procedural provisions to the alcohol excise tax chapter.

### §5561. Exemptions to meet the requirements of the national defense

This section authorizes the Secretary to temporarily exempt distilled spirits plant proprietors from internal revenue laws (except tax payment requirements) when necessary to meet national defense requirements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides national defense exemptions for distilled spirits plants.

### §5562. Exemptions from certain requirements in cases of disaster

This section authorizes the Secretary to temporarily exempt distilled spirits plant proprietors from internal revenue laws (except tax payment requirements) when necessary by reason of disaster.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides disaster-related exemptions for distilled spirits plants.

### §5601. Criminal penalties

This section establishes criminal penalties (fines up to $10,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both) for various offenses related to distilled spirits, including possessing unregistered stills, operating without registration or bond, filing false applications, distilling on prohibited premises, unlawful production or removal of spirits, unauthorized processing, creating fictitious proof, and operating after notice of suspension.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes criminal penalties for distilled spirits violations, which are excise tax enforcement matters.

### §5602. Penalty for tax fraud by distiller

This section imposes a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both, on any person in the distilling business who defrauds or attempts to defraud the United States of distilled spirits tax. No prosecution may be discontinued without written permission of the Attorney General.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns criminal penalties for distiller tax fraud.

### §5603. Penalty relating to records, returns, and reports

This section imposes penalties for fraudulent noncompliance (up to $10,000 fine or 5 years imprisonment) and for non-fraudulent failure to comply (up to $1,000 fine or 1 year imprisonment) with recordkeeping, return, and reporting requirements under the distilled spirits chapter.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes penalties for violations of distilled spirits recordkeeping requirements.

### §5604. Penalties relating to marks, brands, and containers

This section imposes penalties (up to $10,000 fine or 5 years imprisonment) for various offenses involving marks, brands, and containers of distilled spirits, including transporting spirits without proper closures, emptying containers without breaking closures, failing to efface marks on emptied containers, reusing bottles, and altering or counterfeiting marks and brands.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns criminal penalties for distilled spirits container violations.

### §5605. Penalty relating to return of materials used in the manufacture of distilled spirits, or from which distilled spirits may be recovered

This section imposes a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 2 years, or both, on any person who willfully violates the return requirements of section 5291(a), and on any officer, director, or agent who knowingly participates in such violation.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for violations of distilled spirits materials reporting requirements.

### §5606. Penalty relating to containers of distilled spirits

This section imposes a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both, for violating the container regulations of section 5301 or the terms of any permit issued under that section.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for distilled spirits container violations.

### §5607. Penalty and forfeiture for unlawful use, recovery, or concealment of denatured distilled spirits, or articles

This section imposes a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both, for unlawful use of denatured spirits in medicines or beverages, unlawful withdrawal for beverage purposes, sale for beverage purposes, or unauthorized recovery of spirits from denatured products. All personal property and premises involved are subject to forfeiture.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for misuse of denatured distilled spirits.

### §5608. Penalty and forfeiture for fraudulent claims for export drawback or unlawful relanding

This section imposes penalties for fraudulently claiming or obtaining export drawback on distilled spirits (triple the wrongful amount plus up to 5 years imprisonment) and for unlawful relanding of exported spirits (up to $5,000 fine or 3 years imprisonment). Vessels involved in fraudulent export or relanding are subject to forfeiture.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for export fraud involving distilled spirits.

### §5609. Destruction of unregistered stills, distilling apparatus, equipment, and materials

This section authorizes seizing officers to destroy unregistered stills, distilling equipment, and unpaid-tax spirits when removal to safe storage is impracticable. Owners may apply within one year for reimbursement if the property was not used in violation of law or any unlawful use was without their knowledge.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns destruction and forfeiture of illegal distilling equipment.

### §5610. Disposal of forfeited equipment and material for distilling

This section provides that forfeited distilling equipment, condemned material, and related items shall be sold at public auction or otherwise disposed of as directed by the court in which forfeiture was recovered.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns disposal of forfeited distilling equipment.

### §5611. Release of distillery before judgment

This section allows courts to release a seized distillery to a court-appointed receiver to continue operations pending final judgment, upon posting of a bond for the full appraised value of seized property.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns pre-judgment release of seized distilleries.

### §5612. Forfeiture of taxpaid distilled spirits remaining on bonded premises

This section provides that no taxpaid distilled spirits shall be stored on bonded premises, subject to forfeiture, with exceptions for spirits in the process of prompt removal and spirits returned to bonded premises under section 5215.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns forfeiture rules for spirits on bonded premises.

### §5613. Forfeiture of distilled spirits not closed, marked, or branded as required by law

This section provides for forfeiture of distilled spirits found in casks or packages that do not bear required marks, brands, or identification, and spirits in containers that do not bear required closures or devices.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns forfeiture of improperly marked distilled spirits.

### §5614. Burden of proof in cases of seizure of spirits

This section places the burden of proof on the claimant of seized distilled spirits to show no fraud and full tax compliance whenever spirits are seized outside authorized locations or found in violation of law.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns the burden of proof in distilled spirits seizure cases.

### §5615. Property subject to forfeiture

This section enumerates categories of property subject to forfeiture, including unregistered stills, distilling apparatus set up without notice, property connected with distilling without bond or with intent to defraud, spirits produced in violation at vinegar plants, records falsified with intent to defraud, unlawfully removed spirits, and spirits with fictitious proof.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section lists property forfeitable under distilled spirits laws.

### §5661. Penalty and forfeiture for violation of laws and regulations relating to wine

This section imposes penalties for fraudulent wine violations (up to $5,000 fine or 5 years imprisonment, with forfeiture of products and materials) and for non-fraudulent violations (up to $1,000 fine or 1 year imprisonment).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns criminal penalties for wine law violations.

### §5662. Penalty for alteration of wine labels

This section imposes a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year for materially altering required marks or labels on wine, misrepresenting wine identity or origin, or representing still wine as effervescent wine.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for wine label fraud.

### §5663. Cross reference

This section provides a cross reference to Part IV for penalties of common application pertaining to liquors, including wines.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This is a cross-reference within wine penalty provisions.

### §5671. Penalty and forfeiture for evasion of beer tax and fraudulent noncompliance with requirements

This section imposes a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years, or both, for evading beer tax or fraudulently failing to keep records and file returns, with forfeiture of all beer and brewing vessels and apparatus.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns criminal penalties for beer tax evasion.

### §5672. Penalty for failure of brewer to comply with requirements and to keep records and file returns

This section imposes a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both, for non-fraudulent failure to keep required records, file returns, permit inspection, or comply with brewery regulations.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for brewer regulatory noncompliance.

### §5673. Forfeiture for flagrant and willful removal of beer without taxpayment

This section provides that for flagrant and willful removal of beer for consumption or sale with intent to defraud, all right, title, and interest of each knowing person in the brewery lands and buildings shall be forfeited by a proceeding in rem in the appropriate District Court.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns forfeiture for beer tax fraud.

### §5674. Penalty for unlawful production or removal of beer

This section imposes a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both, for brewing or producing beer outside a qualified brewery (with an exception for personal or family use under section 5053(e)) and for removing beer from a brewery without complying with applicable requirements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for unlawful beer production or removal.

### §5675. Penalty for intentional removal or defacement of brewer's marks and brands

This section imposes a $50 penalty per container for any person (other than the owner or authorized agent) who intentionally removes or defaces marks, brands, or labels required by section 5412.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for defacing brewery marks and labels.

### [§5676. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This repealed section formerly related to penalties relating to beer stamps.

### §5681. Penalty relating to signs

This section imposes penalties for failure to post required signs at distilled spirits plants (up to $1,000 fine or 1 year imprisonment), for posting false signs indicating qualification as a distiller or wholesale dealer (up to $1,000 fine or 1 year imprisonment), and for working at or carrying spirits to a plant without proper signs (up to $1,000 fine or 1 year imprisonment, plus forfeiture of vehicles).

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns signage penalties for distilled spirits businesses.

### §5682. Penalty for breaking locks or gaining access

This section imposes a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment up to 3 years, or both, for destroying, breaking, or tampering with any lock or seal placed by an internal revenue officer or distilled spirits plant proprietor, or for gaining unauthorized access to locked premises.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for tampering with government locks on alcohol premises.

### §5683. Penalty and forfeiture for removal of liquors under improper brands

This section imposes a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both, plus forfeiture, for shipping, transporting, or removing distilled spirits, wines, or beer under any other than the proper name or brand designating the kind and quality of the contents.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for mislabeling liquors during transport.

### §5684. Penalties relating to the payment and collection of liquor taxes

This section imposes a 5 percent penalty on anyone who fails to pay any tax imposed by Part I of Subchapter A (liquor taxes) at the prescribed time. It includes cross references to provisions on interest for late payment, failure-to-file penalties, additional penalties for failure to pay, penalties for deposit failures, and criminal penalties for tax evasion.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for liquor tax payment failures, not individual income taxes.

### §5685. Penalty and forfeiture relating to possession of devices for emitting gas, smoke, etc., explosives and firearms, when violating liquor laws

This section imposes severe penalties for possessing gas-emitting devices, explosives, or firearms while violating liquor laws (up to $5,000 fine or 10 years imprisonment for ordinary firearms; up to 20 years imprisonment for machine guns or short-barreled weapons), with forfeiture of all such devices and weapons.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for armed violations of liquor laws.

### §5686. Penalty for having, possessing, or using liquor or property intended to be used in violating provisions of this chapter

This section makes it unlawful to possess liquor or property intended for use in violating the alcohol chapter and imposes a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both. A cross reference directs to section 7302 for seizure and forfeiture provisions.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns penalties for possession of liquor or property intended for violations.

### §5687. Penalty for offenses not specifically covered

This section is a catch-all penalty provision imposing a fine of up to $1,000 or imprisonment up to 1 year, or both, for any violation of the alcohol chapter or regulations for which no specific criminal penalty is prescribed.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section is a residual penalty provision for alcohol law violations.

### §5688. Disposition and release of seized property

This section governs the disposition of forfeited distilled spirits, wines, and beer, requiring delivery to the Administrator of General Services for disposal by delivery to government agencies, gifts to eleemosynary institutions, or destruction. It also addresses sale of spirits under distraint or judicial process (subject to tax) and court authority to refuse return of seized vessels or vehicles.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns the disposition of seized and forfeited alcohol products.

### [§5689. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This repealed section formerly related to penalties for tampering with a stamp machine.

### §5690. Definition of the term "person"

This section defines "person" as used in the liquor penalty subchapter to include an officer or employee of a corporation or a member or employee of a partnership who is under a duty to perform the act with respect to which the violation occurs.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides a definition for the liquor penalty provisions.

### [§5691. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This repealed section formerly related to penalties for nonpayment of special (occupational) taxes on liquor.

### [§5692. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This repealed section formerly related to cross-references regarding failure to post special tax stamps.

### §5701. Rate of tax

This section imposes excise taxes on tobacco products manufactured in or imported into the United States, setting specific rates for small cigars ($50.33 per thousand), large cigars (52.75% of sale price, capped at 40.26 cents per cigar), small cigarettes ($50.33 per thousand), large cigarettes ($105.69 per thousand), cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, snuff ($1.51 per pound), chewing tobacco (50.33 cents per pound), pipe tobacco ($2.8311 per pound), and roll-your-own tobacco ($24.78 per pound). Taxes on imported products are in addition to import duties.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes excise taxes on manufacturers and importers of tobacco products, not individual taxpayers filing income tax returns. Consumers bear these taxes indirectly through product prices but do not report them on personal returns.

### §5702. Definitions

This section defines key terms used throughout the tobacco products chapter, including "cigar," "cigarette," "tobacco products," "manufacturer of tobacco products," "cigarette paper," "cigarette tube," "export warehouse," "removal," "importer," "smokeless tobacco," "pipe tobacco," "roll-your-own tobacco," and "manufacturer of processed tobacco." It also provides rules for determining cigar prices for tax purposes.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides technical definitions for tobacco excise tax purposes.

### §5703. Liability for tax and method of payment

This section establishes that manufacturers and importers of tobacco products are liable for excise taxes imposed by section 5701. It provides for transfer of liability when products are transferred between bonded premises and specifies that taxes are determined at the time of removal, paid on the basis of returns with semimonthly periods. It includes special rules for imported articles, products from Puerto Rico, September payments, and electronic fund transfer requirements.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs the liability and payment mechanisms for tobacco excise taxes by manufacturers and importers.

### §5704. Exemption from tax

This section provides exemptions from tobacco excise tax for products furnished for employee use or experimental purposes, products transferred in bond or removed for export, products released from customs custody for delivery to export warehouses or manufacturers, and previously exported products returned to the original manufacturer.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides excise tax exemptions for tobacco product manufacturers and export warehouse proprietors.

### §5705. Credit, refund, or allowance of tax

This section allows credit or refund of tobacco excise tax to manufacturers, importers, or export warehouse proprietors for tax paid on products withdrawn from the market or lost or destroyed (other than by theft). Claims must be filed within 6 months after the withdrawal, loss, or destruction.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns excise tax credits and refunds for tobacco businesses.

### §5706. Drawback of tax

This section allows a drawback of tax paid on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes when shipped from the United States, in accordance with regulations and upon filing of bond prescribed by the Secretary.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns excise tax drawback for exported tobacco products.

### [§5707. Repealed]

This section has been repealed and is no longer in effect.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This repealed section formerly related to floor stocks refunds on cigarettes.

### §5708. Losses caused by disaster

This section authorizes the Secretary to reimburse persons for internal revenue taxes and customs duties paid on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes that were lost, rendered unmarketable, or condemned due to a major disaster declared by the President under the Stafford Disaster Relief Act. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the presidential determination.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section provides disaster relief for tobacco excise taxes paid by businesses.

### §5711. Bond

This section requires every person commencing business as a manufacturer of tobacco products or cigarette papers and tubes, or as an export warehouse proprietor, to file a bond conditioned upon compliance with the chapter. Bonds must be approved before the person may engage in business and may be canceled if they no longer adequately protect revenue.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs bonding requirements for tobacco businesses.

### §5712. Application for permit

This section requires every person before commencing business as a manufacturer or importer of tobacco products or processed tobacco, or as an export warehouse proprietor, to apply for a permit. Applications may be rejected if the premises are inadequate, minimum capacity requirements are not met, or the applicant's background or conduct raises concerns about compliance.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns permit applications for tobacco businesses.

### §5713. Permit

This section requires a permit to engage in business as a manufacturer or importer of tobacco products or processed tobacco, or as an export warehouse proprietor. Permits are conditioned on compliance and may be suspended or revoked after a show cause hearing if the holder has violated laws, conditions, or disclosure requirements, or has been convicted of felony violations related to tobacco products.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs permits for tobacco businesses.

### §5721. Inventories

This section requires every manufacturer or importer of tobacco products, processed tobacco, or cigarette papers and tubes, and every export warehouse proprietor, to make true and accurate inventories at the time of commencing and concluding business, and at other prescribed times.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes inventory requirements on tobacco businesses.

### §5722. Reports

This section requires every manufacturer or importer of tobacco products, processed tobacco, or cigarette papers and tubes, and every export warehouse proprietor, to make reports as prescribed by the Secretary.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes reporting requirements on tobacco businesses.

### §5723. Packages, marks, labels, and notices

This section requires all tobacco products, processed tobacco, and cigarette papers and tubes to be put up in prescribed packages bearing required marks, labels, and notices before removal. It prohibits lottery features and indecent or immoral material on packages and provides exemptions for employee-use products and in-bond transfers.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs packaging and labeling requirements for tobacco products.

### §5731. Imposition and rate of tax

This section imposes an annual occupational tax of $1,000 ($500 for small proprietors with gross receipts under $500,000) on manufacturers of tobacco products, manufacturers of cigarette papers and tubes, and export warehouse proprietors, for each premises at which business is carried on. Willful failure to pay is punishable by up to $5,000 fine or 2 years imprisonment.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes occupational taxes on tobacco businesses.

### §5732. Payment of tax

This section requires payment of the special occupational tax before engaging in any trade or business subject to the tobacco occupational tax. The tax is computed annually as of July 1, or proportionately from the month of commencing business, and is paid on the basis of a return with the Secretary issuing a stamp receipt.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section governs payment mechanics for tobacco occupational taxes.

### §5733. Provisions relating to liability for occupational taxes

This section provides rules for tobacco occupational tax liability, including that partners pay only one tax, multiple businesses at the same location each require separate tax, businesses in multiple locations require tax for each place, and successors or relocating persons may carry on business without additional tax for the remainder of the taxable period.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns occupational tax liability rules for tobacco businesses.

### §5734. Application of State laws

This section provides that payment of the federal tobacco occupational tax does not exempt any person from state penalties or authorize business contrary to state or municipal law, and does not prohibit states from imposing their own taxes on the same business.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section concerns the relationship between federal tobacco taxes and state laws.

### §5741. Records to be maintained

This section requires every manufacturer of tobacco products, processed tobacco, or cigarette papers and tubes, every importer, and every export warehouse proprietor to keep records prescribed by the Secretary, available for inspection by internal revenue officers during business hours.

**Relevance to personal tax filing:** Not relevant. This section imposes recordkeeping requirements on tobacco businesses.

### §5751. Purchase, receipt, possession, or sale of tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes, after removal

This section prohibits the knowing purchase, receipt, possession, or sale of tobacco products or cigarette papers and tubes on which tax has not been paid or which have been diverted from tax-exempt purposes, or which are not in proper packages bearing required marks and labels. Violators of the intent-to-defraud provisions are liable for a tax equal to the tax on such articles.
